{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox building |name = 14 Wall Street |image = 14 Wall Street New York.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = 14 Wall Street |former_names = Bankers Trust Company Building |location = 8-20 Wall St., [[Manhattan|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] 10005, [[United States]] |coordinates = {{coord|40|42|28|N|74|00|39|W|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:US-NY}} |status = Complete |architectural_style = [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] |start_date = 1910 |completion_date = 1912 |opening = |building_type = Office |antenna_spire = |height = 540 feet (164.6 m) |top_floor = |floor_count = 29 |elevator_count = 32 |cost = |floor_area = |architect = [[Trowbridge & Livingston]]
[[Shreve, Lamb & Harmon]] (Addition) |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = |owner = |management = |references = }} '''14 Wall Street''', originally the '''Bankers Trust Company Building''', is a [[skyscraper]] at 14 [[Wall Street]] at the corner of [[Nassau Street (Manhattan)|Nassau Street]] and running through to Pine Street in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[Manhattan]] in [[New York City]]. It sits across Nassau Street from [[Federal Hall National Memorial]], across Wall Street from the [[New York Stock Exchange]] and diagonally across from the original headquarters of [[J. P. Morgan & Company]]. It was built in 1910-12 and was designed by [[Trowbridge & Livingston]] in the [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical style]] as the headquarters for [[Bankers Trust]]. An addition with [[Art Deco architecture|Art Deco detailing]], designed by [[Shreve, Lamb & Harmon]], was constructed in 1931-33. The stepped pyramid at the building's top is a noted part of the downtown skyline, and became the logo for Bankers Trust, which sold the building in 1937.{{cite nycland}}, p. 14 The building was designated a [[List of New York City Landmarks|New York City landmark]] on January 14, 1997.Harris, Gale. [http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/14Wall.pdf "Bankers Trust Building Designation Report"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303193819/http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/14Wall.pdf |date=March 3, 2016 }} [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] (January 14, 1997) == History == {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | image1 = Tombeau de Mausole (Barclay) crop.jpg | width1 = 138 | caption1 = Artist's conception of the [[Mausoleum of Halicarnassus]] | image2 = CampanileSanMarco.jpg | width2 = 124 | caption2 = [[St Mark's Campanile]] }} The concept behind the building's design was to place the [[Mausoleum of Halicarnassus]] on top of [[St Mark's Campanile]] in Venice. Many early skyscrapers took the Venetian bell-tower as a logical model for a modern office tower, but 14 Wall Street was the first to top it off with a temple in the sky, a seven-story stepped pyramid modeled on one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. [[Bankers Trust]], for whom the building was constructed, then adopted the pyramid as its trademark, and took as its slogan "A Tower of Strength". The first stage of construction, 1910–1912, was marked by the demolition of a 20-story [[Gillender Building]], claimed to be the first skyscraper demolished to make way for a taller skyscraper.{{ cite news | title=Skyscraper Going: Higher One Coming. Razing 20-Story Gillender Building to Make Room for 32-Story Bankers' Trust Home | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1910/04/30/archives/skyscraper-going-higher-one-coming-razing-20story-gillender.html |work=The New York Times|date=April 30, 1910 | accessdate=December 31, 2008 }} It was completed in 1912 and is {{convert|539|ft|m}} tall with 37 floors. In its day the world's tallest bank building, the skyscraper originally housed the headquarters of [[Bankers Trust]], which was founded in 1903 when a number of commercial banks needed a vehicle to enter the trusts and estates market; fourteen years later it became a full-service bank, and one of the country's wealthiest financial institutions. The bank occupied only the three lower floors; its main operations were housed elsewhere in less expensive offices.Willis, p. 150 Most of the remainder of the building was rental property. The 31st floor was once an apartment belonging to [[J. P. Morgan]]. The space was converted into an upscale French restaurant called "The 14 Wall Street." However, the restaurant closed in April 2006,{{ cite web | url=http://search.cityguide.aol.com/newyork/restaurants/closed-14-wall-street-restaurant/v-106895771 | title=14 Wall St Restaurant Closed | publisher=AOL Cityguide | accessdate=January 1, 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830083922/http://search.cityguide.aol.com/newyork/restaurants/closed-14-wall-street-restaurant/v-106895771 | archive-date=August 30, 2008 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }} following plans in 2004 to convert the entire building from offices into luxury condos.{{ cite news | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FOS/is_2004_May_12/ai_n6265860 | title=Whitehall team set to market 14 Wall Street | publisher=Real Estate Alert|date=May 12, 2004 | accessdate=January 1, 2009 }} On January 21, 2007, the building's owners, having stalled in their residential conversion plan, agreed to sell the property to [[Cushman & Wakefield]]. {{ cite news | url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/01222007/business/cushman_in_325m_deal_for_14_wall_st__business_lois_weiss.htm | title=Cushman in %325M deal for 14 Wall St. | work=New York Post | accessdate=January 1, 2009 | first=Lois | last=Weiss | date=January 22, 2007 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829195752/http://www.nypost.com/seven/01222007/business/cushman_in_325m_deal_for_14_wall_st__business_lois_weiss.htm | archive-date=August 29, 2008 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}{{ cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/21/realestate/21scap.html| title=Bankers Trust: The Building Known for Its Ziggurat Top | author=Gray, Christopher |work=The New York Times|date=January 21, 2007 | accessdate=January 1, 2009 }} The Morgan apartment is now used by the international IT services provider, [[FDM Group]], which kept many of the original features, including the bar, fireplace and wooden flooring. In April 2012, majority control of the building was sold for $303 million in cash to [[Alexander Rovt]], a fertilizer tycoon from Ukraine, who paid off the building's outstanding debt as part of the deal. Rovt, who is listed as #372 on the ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]'' list of the 400 wealthiest Americans, paid less than the $325 million building had sold for in 2007, at the peak of the real estate boom. At the time of the purchase, it had 300,000 square feet of vacant space, and three potential tenants were in discussion to lease about two-thirds of that amount.Satow, Julie. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/11/realestate/commercial/alex-rovt-buys-14-wall-street-for-303-million.html "Square Feet: Fertilizer Billionaire Buys Buildings His Way, in Cash"] ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 11, 2012 ==See also== *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in New York County, New York]] *[[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan]] ==Tenants== *[[NYU Langone Medical Center]] *[[Amerigroup]] *[[FDM Group]] *[[Market America]] *[[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] *[[TheStreet.com]] *[[Merchant Capital INC]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|14 Wall Street}} * {{Official website|http://www.14wall.com/}} * [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=114527 Emporis.com] – Building ID 114527 [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Wall Street]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1912]] [[Category:1912 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in New York City]]

{{Infobox person |name = Anson Green Phelps |image = Anson-greene-phelps-b1781.jpg |image size = 150px |caption = Anson Green Phelps, industrialist and philanthropist |birth_date = {{Birth date|1781|03|24}} |birth_place = Simsbury, Connecticut |death_date = {{Death date and age|1853|11|30|1781|11|30}} |death_place = New York City, New York |other_names = |known_for = Founder Phelps Dodge Mining Corporation |occupation = |nationality = American |resting_place=New York Marble Cemetery, re-interred, Green-Wood Cemetery |signature = Sig-anson-greene-phelps.gif}} '''Anson Green Phelps''' (March 24, 1781 – November 30, 1853) was an American entrepreneur and business man from Connecticut. Beginning with a saddlery business, he founded [[Phelps Dodge|Phelps, Dodge & Co.]] in 1833 as an export-import business with his sons-in-law [[William E. Dodge]] and [[Daniel James (businessman)|Daniel James]] based as partners in [[Liverpool]], England. His third son-in-law, [[James Boulter Stokes]], became a partner some years later. Later in the 19th century after the senior Phelps' death, Phelps Dodge acquired mining interests and companies in the American West, and became known primarily as a mining company. == Early life == Anson Green Phelps was born in [[Simsbury, Connecticut]], in 1781; his mother died when he was 12 years old. Afterward, he was raised in the house of the [[Congregational]] minister of Simsbury. Phelps was descended from the early American colonial governors [[Thomas Dudley]], [[John Haynes (governor)|John Haynes]] and [[George Wyllys]]. On October 13, 1799, he chose a relative, Thomas Woodbridge Phelps, as his guardian. On May 5, 1799, Thomas Woodbridge Phelps and Anson Green Phelps were admitted to the [[Congregational Church]] in [[Canton, Connecticut|South Canton, Connecticut]], which was led by Reverend Jeremiah Hallock. In his early adulthood, Anson Phelps left Simsbury and settled in [[Hartford, Connecticut]].{{cite book|title=The Phelps Family of America and Their English Ancestors|author=Phelps, Judge Oliver Seymour and Andrew T. Servin| publisher=Eagle Publishing Company|location=Pittsfield, Massachusetts| year=1899}}{{rp|1409–1412}} == Career == After moving to Hartford, Phelps began manufacturing saddles and shipping them to the South. His business grew rapidly. He had a large brick building constructed on North Main street, which became known as the "Phelps Block." In 1812 he moved to [[New York City]] and began doing business with [[Elisha Peck (Merchant)|Elisha Peck]] under the firm name of Phelps, Peck & Co. in the United States. In [[Liverpool]], [[England]], where Peck managed it, the firm was known as Peck, Phelps & Co. They dealt in metal imports from England including tin, tin plate, iron, and brass; and exported cotton from the South to the textile mills in England. Such cotton trade was highly important to England and contributed to its considering support for the Confederacy during the American Civil War. Fellow businessman Sheldon Smith persuaded Phelps to invest in the growing town of [[Derby, Connecticut]], in an area that came to be known as Birmingham. Unable to grow his business farther north, Phelps selected a location on the east bank of the [[Naugatuck River]] in what is now downtown [[Ansonia, Connecticut|Ansonia]]. Ansonia was first settled in 1652 and named in honor of Anson Phelps. The state chartered Ansonia as a borough of Derby in 1864, and later as a separate town in 1889. In 1893, Ansonia incorporated as a city, consolidating with the boundaries of the town. Phelps' business continued to prosper and he accumulated a large fortune. His original partnership with Peck was dissolved in 1832 following the destruction of their New York warehouse (4 May 1832) due to structural failure. Phelps and his son narrowly escaped, but among the dead was Josiah Stokes, a senior clerk who was betrothed to Phelps daughter, Caroline. This was a terrible blow to Phelps and his family. He reorganized the business, forming the [[Phelps Dodge]] Company in 1833 with his sons-in-law [[William Earl Dodge]] and [[Daniel James (businessman)|Daniel James]] as partners. The two of them operated the firm's functions in Liverpool, England. In 1839 Phelps made his son Anson G. Phelps, Jr. a partner, with a one-eighth share of the business. Caroline Phelps eventually married James Boulter Stokes, brother of the dead Josiah. He became the third son-in-law of Phelps to join Phelps, Dodge & Co. as a partner.{{cite book|last=Cleland|first=Robert Glass|title=A History of Phelps Dodge|date=1952|publisher=Alfred A Knopf|location=New York|page=15}} Stokes was wealthy in his own right. During the 1837 financial crisis, he helped the Phelps, Dodge partnership through a difficult time with a loan. Phelps' business interests included banking, property, mining, ironworks, shipping, railroads and timber. After the split with Peck, some of these interests were divided between the two men. Others remained in joint partnership, including the New York property portfolio and shipping. Peck, who took over the rolling mill at Haverstraw, would continue to purchase raw materials from Phelps.{{cite book|last=Cleland|first=Robert Glass|title=A History of Phelps Dodge|date=1952|publisher=Alfred A Knopf|location=New York|page=17}} ==Philanthropic interests== Phelps continued to be an active member of the Congregational Church, and he took an interest in a number of philanthropic causes. He contributed generously to the [[American Bible Society]], the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]], the [[American Home Missionary Society]], the [[American Colonization Society|Colonization Society]], the Blind Asylum of New York City, and served as the president of each at some point during his life. He also contributed to many other societies and charitable institutions both while he lived and through his estate. He gave his native town of [[Simsbury, Connecticut]] US$1000 to aid the poor. Among his other philanthropic activities was the creation of the Anson G. Phelps lecture series on early American history at [[New York University]]. In the 1830s, Phelps supported Presbyterian preacher [[Charles Grandison Finney]] during his ministry in New York. Phelps first hired a church for him in Vanderwater Street, and later purchased a church in Princes Street, near Broadway. Finney was "much struck with the piety of Mr Phelps", and said that Phelps would rise at night so that he could commune with God, having little time for secret devotion during the day, when business pressed him.{{cite book|last=Rosell/Dupuis|first=Garth/Richard|title=The Original Memoirs of Charles G Finney|year=1989|publisher=Zondervan|location=Michigan|pages=Chapter XX Revivals in Columbia and New York City}} == Family == Phelps married [[Olivia Egleston]], daughter of Elihu and Elizabeth Egleston, on 26 October 1806 at the age of 25. He and Olivia had nine children: Elizabeth, Melissa, Caroline Olivia (died in infancy), and Caroline, all born in Hartford; and Harriett, Anson Green Jr., Olivia Egleston, and Lydia Ann, all born in New York City. His grandsons included [[Anson Phelps Stokes]] and [[William Earl Dodge Stokes]]. His great-grandson, [[Anson Phelps Stokes (philanthropist)|Anson Phelps Stokes]], became a well-known philanthropist. In 1835 Phelps purchased the house of Henry A. Coster and added land to extend the property from Third Avenue to the [[East River]], and from Twenty-ninth to half-way between Thirty-third and Thirty-fourth streets.{{cite book|last1=Stokes|first1=Anson Phelps|title=Stokes Records Vol 1|date=1910|publisher=Privately printed|page=13}} {{chart top|width=100%}} {{chart/start|align=center}} {{chart| | | | | | | | | | | | | | |AGS| |AGS=Anson Green Phelps
(1781-1853)

(1823-1831)}} {{chart/end}} {{chart bottom}} == Death and bequests == Phelps died at his New York residence, formerly the Coster place, on 30 November 1853 at age 73. He left about two million dollar, of which almost seven hundred thousand was his shares in Phelps Dodge & Co. These were purchased by the other partners. Just over one million dollars was property in New York, Indiana, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Missouri. His will was contested and there were so many anomalies that his widow, who was the executrix, put it before the courts to sort out. It was after her death that the final verdict was given by the court of appeal in 1861. Due to a technical issue with the wording of the will, one large bequest of $50,000 to the Liberia College was declared void by the courts. However, the family held this bequest to be sacred and the donation stood despite the ruling.{{cite book|last1=Lowitt|first1=Richard|title=A Merchant Prince of the 19th Century|date=1954|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York}} He was eulogized by a Mrs. Sigourney in writing: {{cquote|The cares of commerce and the rush of wealth Swept not away his meekness, nor the time To cultivate all household charities; Nor the answering, conscientious zeal To consecrate a portion of his gains To man's relief and the Redeemer's cause.}}{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} In his will, Phelps left instructions to his heirs in terms that characterized his life: {{cquote|I give and bequeath to each of my grand-children, living at my decease, the sum of $5,000, to be paid them as they severally attain the age of 21 years. This latter bequest I direct to be accompanied by my executors with this injunction:-That each of my said grand-children shall consider the said bequest as a sacred deposit, committed to their trust, to be invested by each grand-child, and the income derived therefrom to be devoted to spread the gospel, and to promote the Redeemer's kingdom oil earth, hoping and trusting that the God of Heaven will give to each of that wisdom which is from above, and incline them to be faithful stewards, and transmit the same to their descendants, to be sacredly devoted to the same object. I know this bequest is absolute and places the amount so given beyond my control; but my earnest hope is that my wish may be regarded as I leave it, an obligation binding simply on their integrity and honor.}} His funeral was at the Presbyterian Church, Mercer Street, New York, where he had been a ruling elder. He was buried in his family vault in the [[New York Marble Cemetery]]. He was later re-interred in the [[Green-Wood Cemetery]] in Brooklyn.{{cite news|title=Funeral of Anson Greene Phelps|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1858/05/21/101002298.pdf|accessdate=8 November 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=21 May 1858}}{{cite news|title=Workmen Reveal an Old Cemetery|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/11/04/104999239.pdf|accessdate=8 November 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=4 November 1907}} == See also == * [[Ansonia, Connecticut]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.phelpsfamilyhistory.com/bios/anson_g_phelps.asp Biography] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Phelps, Anson Green}} [[Category:1781 births]] [[Category:1853 deaths]] [[Category:Ansonia, Connecticut]] [[Category:Phelps Dodge]] [[Category:18th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Burials at Green-Wood Cemetery]] [[Category:People from Simsbury, Connecticut]] [[Category:Dodge family]] [[Category:19th-century merchants]]

{{Infobox NRHP | name =Bagley Memorial Fountain | nrhp_type = | image = BagleyMemorialFountainDetroit.jpg | caption = Bagley Memorial Fountain at its new location on [[Campus Martius Park#Cadillac Square Park|Cadillac Square]] facing [[Campus Martius Park|Campus Martius]] | location= Cadillac Square
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | coordinates = {{coord|42|19|53|N|83|2|42|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built =1885 | architect= [[H. H. Richardson]] | architecture= Italian RomanesqueNawrocki, Dennis Alan, ''Art in Detroit Public Places'', Wayne State University Press, Detroit, Michigan, 1980 p. 22 | added = November 05, 1971 | governing_body = Local | refnum=71000422{{NRISref|2008a}} | designated_other1= Michigan State Historic Site | designated_other1_link = Michigan State Historic Preservation Office | designated_other1_date = March 3, 1971{{cite web|title=Bagley Memorial Fountain |publisher=Michigan State Housing Development Authority |url=http://www.mcgi.state.mi.us/hso/sites/24747.htm |accessdate=September 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120517132347/http://www.mcgi.state.mi.us/hso/sites/24747.htm |archivedate=May 17, 2012 |df= }} | designated_other1_num_position = bottom }} The '''Bagley Memorial Fountain''' is a historic fountain in [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]] [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. It has recently been moved from its long-time location in [[Campus Martius Park]] to a new location in just down the street in [[Campus Martius Park#Cadillac Square Park|Cadillac Square Park]]. The fountain was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and designated a Michigan State Historic Site in 1971. The [[John N. Bagley House]] (1889) at 2921 East Jefferson Avenue in Detroit was constructed for Governor Bagley's son, and is also listed on the National Register of Historic Places. ==John J. Bagley== [[File:LionsBagleyMemorialFountainDetroit.jpg|left|thumb|Lion detail on fountain]] [[File:WoodwardAve1891.jpg|left|thumb|Woodward Avenue c. 1891 showing Bagley Fountain (far left)]] [[John J. Bagley]] was the 16th governor of Michigan, serving from 1873 to 1877.[http://www.ci.detroit.mi.us/historic/districts/bagley_fountain.pdf Bagley Memorial Fountain] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011105807/http://www.ci.detroit.mi.us/historic/districts/bagley_fountain.pdf |date=2007-10-11 }} from the city of Detroit Bagley also served as a Detroit Alderman from 1860–61 and as Police Commissioner from 1865-72. He was instrumental in the creation of the Detroit Metropolitan Police Commission and the construction of the first [[Detroit House of Corrections]]. When Bagley died in 1881, his will contained $5,000 for the construction of a drinking fountain for the people of Detroit, having "water cold and pure as the coldest mountain stream." ==Fountain== In 1885, the Bagley family chose [[Henry Hobson Richardson]] to design the fountain.[https://books.google.com/books?id=gBDXfLHsnc4C Jeffrey Karl Ochsner,] ''H.H. Richardson, Complete Architectural Works,'' MIT Press, 1982, {{ISBN|0-262-65015-0}}, p. 400. In 1887, the Bagley Memorial Fountain was dedicated at the corner of [[Woodward Avenue]] and Fort Street. Richardson constructed the fountain entirely out of pink [[Bragville granite]], modeled after a [[Ciborium (architecture)|ciborium]] located in [[St. Mark's Basilica]] in [[Venice]]. The Bagley Memorial Fountain stands 21 feet high with a basin 7 feet across. At the center of the fountain, four lion heads distribute water. In the original design, two of the heads produced "normal" temperature water and the other two produced cold water, chilled by ice packed around the fountain pipes. The inscription on the four sides of the cornice reads: TESTAMENTARY GIFT | FOR THE PEOPLE FROM | JOHN JVDSON BAGLEY | A.D. MDCCCLXXXVII. ==Later moves== In 1926 the fountain was moved from its original home at Woodward and Fort to Campus Martius, because of the increase of automobile traffic. In 2000, the fountain was removed from it site, disassembled, and put into storage.[http://www.dwsd.org/announce/flow/InTheFlow_winter_2007.pdf "Bagley Fountain Makes a Comeback,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513142349/http://www.dwsd.org/announce/flow/InTheFlow_winter_2007.pdf |date=2008-05-13 }} ''In the Flow,'' Detroit Water and Sewerage Department, V7 n1 (Winter 2007) In 2007, the fountain was installed in its current location in Cadillac Square; a new lion fountainhead replaced the original, which was stolen. It is the only remaining work by Richardson in the Detroit area. ==See also== *[[Drinking fountains in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Downtown Detroit}} [[Category:Fountains in Michigan]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Michigan]] [[Category:Downtown Detroit]] [[Category:Drinking fountains in the United States]] [[Category:Granite sculptures in Michigan]] [[Category:1885 sculptures]] [[Category:Michigan State Historic Sites in Wayne County, Michigan]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Detroit]] [[Category:1885 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Detroit]] [[Category:Relocated buildings and structures in Michigan]] [[Category:Henry Hobson Richardson buildings]] [[Category:Richardsonian Romanesque architecture in Michigan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Detroit]]

{{Infobox person | name = Barry J. Klarberg | image = Barry Klarberg.jpg | caption = Barry Klarberg at 2015 Pace University Commencement | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|3|4}} | birth_place = [[Rockaway, Queens]], New York, U.S. | occupation = Entertainment & Sports Business Manager and Limited Partner of the New York Yankees <ref name="sportsbusinessdaily">Sports Business Journal. [http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2012/04/09/Labor-and-Agents/Monarch.aspx "Athlete advisors Klarberg, Furst Close to Deal"], April 9, 2012.</ref> | residence = [[Greenwich, Connecticut]] | partner = Sara Herbert (married 2018) | children = 6 (Nikki, Matt, Ryan, Jake, Justin and Alana) }}
'''Barry J. Klarberg''' (born March 4, 1961), CPA, is an American businessman. He is a professional business and wealth manager for athletes, entertainers and high-net-worth individuals.<ref name="sportsbusinessdaily" /><ref name="sfgate">San Francisco Chronicle. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2012/03/26/prweb9324314.DTL "Asset Alliance Acquires Equity Interest in Klarberg's Monarch Business and Wealth Management, LLC"], March 26, 2012.</ref> He is the founder and CEO of Monarch Business and Wealth Management, a full-service firm and [[family office]] that specializes in providing business and wealth management services.<ref>[http://www.monarchmgmtllc.com/ "Monarch Wealth and Business Management Homepage"].</ref> Klarberg has managed several prominent individuals including musician/actor [[Justin Timberlake]],<ref name="bare_url">Inside.[http://wjcohen.home.mindspring.com/music/nsyncmsn.htm "Behind Big Bucks 'N Sync-MSN Deal, a Secret Backroom Fixer"] December 2003.</ref> entrepreneur [[Russell Simmons]],<ref name="sdmackpictures">SD Mack. [http://www.sdmackpictures.com/2008-Archive/July/EAST-HAMPTON-July-19-Russell/5484784_sLjjrX/3/335363442_SQ7Td#!i=335363442&k=SQ7Td "Russell Simmons’ 9th Annual Art for Life East Hampton"] July 2008.</ref> DJ and record producer [[Kaskade]], [[NASCAR]] champion [[Kyle Busch]], professional tennis player/model [[Anna Kournikova]],<ref name="sportsbusinessdaily" /> NBA All-Star [[Kyle Lowry]], MLB All-Star and Homerun Champion [[José Bautista]], MLS All-Star and Captain of the United States men's national soccer team [[Michael Bradley (soccer)|Michael Bradley]], and NHL Hall-of-Famer [[Mark Messier]].<ref name="nytimes">New York Times. [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/20/sports/hockey-let-s-hoist-that-banner-will-messier-join-party.html "Let's Hoist That Banner! Will Messier Join Party?"] January 1995.</ref>
Klarberg holds an ownership stake in three American professional sports franchises. He is an owner of the [[New York Yankees]], being a Partner since 2011.<ref>New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/20/sports/baseball/ray-bartoszek-an-investor-who-talked-to-mets-buys-part-of-yankees.html "Investor Who Talked to Mets Buys Part of Yankees"], September 19, 2011.</ref> Klarberg is an owner of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) team [[New York City FC]].<ref>New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/22/sports/soccer/manchester-city-and-yankees-to-own-mls-franchise-in-new-york.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 "Manchester City and Yankees to Own MLS Franchise in New York"], May 21, 2013. </ref>
In the Fall of 2017, Klarberg taught "Business Developments in Sports" at the [[University of Michigan]] in Ann Arbor and during the Fall of 2018, Klarberg will teach again at the [[University of Michigan]].<ref>University of Michigan [https://csprod.dsc.umich.edu/psp/csprodpa/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.M_SR_CRSECAT_HOME1.GBL?FolderPath=PORTAL_ROOT_OBJECT.CO_EMPLOYEE_SELF_SERVICE.M_SR_CRSECAT_HOME1_GBL&IgnoreParamTempl=FolderPath,IsFolder&IsFolder=false&PortalActualURL=https://csprod.dsc.umich.edu/psp/csprodpa/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.M_SR_CRSECAT_HOME1.GBL&PortalContentURL=https://csprod.dsc.umich.edu/psc/csprodpa/EMPLOYEE/HRMS/c/COMMUNITY_ACCESS.M_SR_CRSECAT_HOME1.GBL&PortalContentProvider=HRMS&PortalCRefLabel=Public%20Class%20Search%20Home&PortalRegistryName=EMPLOYEE&PortalServletURI=https://csprod.dsc.umich.edu/psp/csprodpa/&PortalURI=https://csprod.dsc.umich.edu/psc/csprodpa/&PortalHostNode=HRMS&NoCrumbs=yes&PortalKeyStruct=yes "Business Developments in Sports at the University of Michigan"], 2017. </ref>
He regularly appears on CNN, CNBC and The Wall Street Journal Report, and authored the book "Winning Tax Strategies and Planning for Athletes and Entertainers."<ref name="sfgate" /> Klarberg has also been elected to the ''Sports Business Journal's'' "Forty Under 40," as he was selected as one of the forty most influential executives in the sports business under the age of 40.<ref>Sports Business Journal. [http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Conferences-Events/2012/2012-Forty-Under-40-Awards/Previous-Recipients/2000.aspx "Sports Business Journal's Forty Under 40 2000 Recipients"], January 2011.</ref>
In April 2016, Klarberg represented NFL star [[Rob Gronkowski]] and launched with [[Monster Energy]] a signature beverage "Gronk" that will be distributed by [[Coca-Cola]].<ref>Darren Rovell, ESPN [http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14188905/rob-gronkowski-new-england-patriots-signs-monster-energy-drink "Patriots TE Rob Gronkowski signs multiyear deal with Monster drink"], November 21, 2015.</ref>
In May 2016, Klarberg shaped [[Tom Brady]]’s new [[Simmons Bedding Company|Simmons]] Beautyrest Black luxury mattress ad campaign, aiding Simmons’ marketing team in pitching the campaign to the three-time Super Bowl MVP.<ref>Sports Business Journal [https://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2016/05/16/Marketing-and-Sponsorship/The-Lefton-Report.aspx "Simmons Gives Patriots' No. 12 A Shot At Being 007 In New Ad"], May 16, 2016.</ref>
Klarberg was commissioned the honorary title [[Kentucky Colonel]], the highest honor awarded by the Commonwealth of Kentucky, by [[Kentucky]] Governor [[Steven Beshear]].
In 2015, Klarberg gave the commencement address at alma mater [[Pace University]] to the undergraduate Class of 2015 and received an honorary doctorate degree.<ref>Daily Voice [http://pleasantville.dailyvoice.com/schools/pace-alumni-barry-klarberg-helps-top-stars-grow-wealth "Pace Alumni Barry Klarberg Helps Top Stars Grow Wealth"], May 30, 2015.</ref> Klarberg also returned to [[Pace University]] as an Executive-in-Residence and a Lecturer-in-Residence at the [[Lubin School of Business]].<ref>Pace University [http://www.pace.edu/lubin/news-events/executive-in-residence/spring-2015-plv "Pleasantville Lubin School of Business Executives in Residence"], 2015.</ref> Klarberg is a member of the President's Council at Pace University.
==Education and early career== Klarberg received his BBA (1981) and [http://www.pace.edu/lubin/accounting-and-taxation-degree MS in Taxation] (1985) from [[Pace University]]. He was an Adjunct Professor of Taxation at Pace University from 1985–1989. Klarberg began his career at [[Deloitte]] in 1981, where he spent 11 years. At Deloitte, he was the National Director of Sports and Entertainment. In 1992, Klarberg formed KRT Business Management, specializing in professional wealth management services, which he eventually sold to Assante Wealth Management Services.<ref>Sports Business Journal [http://m.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2000/02/20000207/No-Topic-Name/Assante-Scoops-Up-Klarberg-Raiola-Firm.aspx "Assante Scoops Up Klarberg Raiola Firm"], February 7, 2000.</ref><ref>PR Newswire [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Assante+Corporation+Acquires+Leading+New+York+Based+Professional...-a059133257 "Assante Corporation Acquires Leading New York Based Professional Services Firm Klarberg, Raiola & Associates"], January 8, 2000.</ref><ref>Registered Rep. [http://registeredrep.com/planner-ria-practice/finance_show_money/ "Show Me The Money"], June 2002.</ref>
Preceding Monarch, Klarberg spent two years as Senior Managing Director at [[Guggenheim Partners]]. In this role, Klarberg headed up Guggenheim Wealth Services' New York office.<ref>Sports Business Journal. [http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2006/11/20061113/Labor-Agents/Guggenheim-Buys-Adviser-Klarbergs-Firm.aspx "Guggenheim Buys Adviser Klarberg's Firm"], November 2006.</ref>
==Monarch Business & Wealth Management== Klarberg is the founder of Monarch Business & Wealth Management, a financial and life management company and [[family office]] that represents professional athletes, internationally acclaimed entertainers and high-net-worth families. He currently manages entrepreneur [[Russell Simmons]],<ref name="sdmackpictures" /> DJ and record producer [[Kaskade]], several top [[NASCAR]] drivers, [[Anna Kournikova]], MLB All-Star [[C. J. Wilson]], MLB All-Star and Homerun Champion [[José Bautista]] and NHL Hall-of-Famer [[Mark Messier]],<ref name="nytimes" /> amongst others. In 2011, Asset Alliance Corporation, a New York-based private equity firm with more than $1 billion under management, acquired an equity interest in Monarch Business & Wealth Management.<ref>San Francisco Chronicle. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2012/03/26/prweb9324314.DTL#ixzz1qFVSvukR "Asset Alliance Acquires Equity Interest in Monarch Business and Wealth Management, LLC"], March 26, 2012.</ref>
In 2012, the Sports Business Journal reported on Klarberg's expansion of Monarch Management. The report of this expansion included Klarberg's proposed acquisition of Miami-based ASF Consulting, a firm owned by [[Allen Furst]] that represents several current and former MLB and NBA players, including [[Roy Hibbert]], [[Jeff Green (basketball)|Jeff Green]] and [[Alonzo Mourning]].<ref>Sports Business Journal. [http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2012/04/09/Labor-and-Agents/Monarch.aspx "Athlete Advisor Klarberg, Furst Close to Deal"], April 9, 2012.</ref> Klarberg further expanded Monarch when he hired former [[Major League Baseball]] [[starting pitcher]] and United States [[Olympic Games|Olympian]] [[Kris Benson]] as Managing Director at Monarch Business & Wealth Management.<ref>LinkedIn. [http://www.linkedin.com/in/krisbenson34 "LinkedIn Profile for Kris Benson"]</ref>
In 2013, [[CertusBank]], a nationally chartered bank with nearly $2 billion in assets, made a strategic investment in Monarch.<ref>GlobeNewswire. [http://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2013/08/19/567758/10045448/en/CertusBank-to-Make-Strategic-Investment-in-Monarch-Business-and-Wealth-Management-LLC.html "CertusBank to Make Strategic Investment in Monarch Business and Wealth Management LLC"], August 19, 2013.</ref>
In April 2016, Klarberg represented NFL star [[Rob Gronkowski]] and launched with [[Monster Energy]] a signature beverage "Gronk" that will be distributed by [[Coca-Cola]].<ref>Darren Rovell, ESPN [http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14188905/rob-gronkowski-new-england-patriots-signs-monster-energy-drink "Patriots TE Rob Gronkowski signs multiyear deal with Monster drink"], November 21, 2015.</ref>
In 2016, Josh Klein became a partner in Monarch, whose clients include [[The Chainsmokers]], [[Big Sean]], [[Logic (musician)|Logic]], [[DJ Snake]] and [[Kelly Rowland]].
==New York Yankees and Yankees Global Enterprises== In September 2011, Klarberg became a Limited Partner of the [[New York Yankees]]. Teaming up with former Glencore oil commodities trader Ray Bartoszek, the two currently hold an ownership interest in [[Yankee Global Enterprises]] including a stake in the Yankees Entertainment & Sports Network ([[YES Network]]).<ref>David Waldstein, New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/20/sports/baseball/ray-bartoszek-an-investor-who-talked-to-mets-buys-part-of-yankees.html "Investor Talked to Mets But Buys Part of Yankees"], September 20, 2011.</ref> In 2013, Klarberg also became an owner of [[Major League Soccer]] team [[New York City FC]].<ref>New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/22/sports/soccer/manchester-city-and-yankees-to-own-mls-franchise-in-new-york.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 "Manchester City and Yankees to Own MLS Franchise in New York"], May 21, 2013. </ref>
==Personal life== Klarberg is a resident of [[Greenwich, Connecticut]]. He is currently married to charity consultant Sara Herbert-Galloway.
==Community involvement==
Klarberg is actively involved in various charity and community activities including the ''National Meningitis Association'', the [[USO]], and Homeland Security's ''Federal Enforcement Foundation''.<ref name="bare_url_a">Dan's Hamptons. [http://danshamptons.com/2012/03/18/sara-herbert-galloway-and-barry-j-klarberg-to-receive-the-national-meningitis-associations-nancy-ford-springer-inspiration-award/ "Barry J. Klarberg to Receive the National Meningitis Association's Nancy Ford Springer Inspiration Award"] March 18, 2012.</ref> In 2011, Klarberg was selected as an Executive Committee Member of the USO Entertainment Advisory Council, which helps brings professional athletes and entertainers overseas to visit American soldiers.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
In April 2012, Klarberg, along with Sara Herbert-Galloway, was honored with the ''National Meningitis Association'' Nancy Ford Springer Inspiration Award for his long-standing support of NMA’s fight against the vaccine-preventable disease.<ref>Huffington Post [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-luce/meningitis_b_1455100.html "Meningitis: Give Kids a Shot -- Save a Kid's Life"], April 25, 2012.</ref><ref name="NY Daily News">New York Daily News. [http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/gisele-bundchen-tom-brady-show-surprise-hosts-arrive-style-boston-boutique-article-1.1065781?localLinksEnabled=false "Charlie Sheen Wants to Win Against Meningitis"] April 2012.</ref><ref name="bare_url_a" />
In 2012, Klarberg was selected as a member of the 2014 NY/NJ [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] Host Committee.<ref>[http://nynjsuperbowl.com/ "2014 NY/NJ Super Bowl Host Committee"]</ref>
Klarberg and sons Matt and Ryan Klarberg were commissioned the honorary title [[Kentucky Colonel]], the highest honor awarded by the Commonwealth of Kentucky, in 2012 by [[Kentucky]] Governor [[Steven Beshear]], in recognition of their noteworthy accomplishments and outstanding service to the greater community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Barry Klarberg|url=http://barryklarberg.org/|website=barryklarberg.org|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2015, Klarberg gave the commencement address at alma mater [[Pace University]] to the undergraduate Class of 2015 and received an honorary doctorate degree.<ref>Daily Voice [http://pleasantville.dailyvoice.com/schools/pace-alumni-barry-klarberg-helps-top-stars-grow-wealth "Pace Alumni Barry Klarberg Helps Top Stars Grow Wealth"], May 30, 2015.</ref> Klarberg also returned to [[Pace University]] as an Executive-in-Residence and a Lecturer-in-Residence at the [[Lubin School of Business]].<ref>Pace University [http://www.pace.edu/lubin/news-events/executive-in-residence/spring-2015-plv "Spring 2015 - Pleasantville Lubin School of Business - Pace University - Executives in Residence"], 2015.</ref> {{-}} Klarberg is a member of the President's Council at Pace University.
In the Fall of 2017, Klarberg taught "Business Developments in Sports" in the Sport Management Program at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and during the Fall of 2018, Klarberg will teach again at the [[University of Michigan]].

Idhifa | revenue = {{unbulleted list|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 13.51 billion (2017){{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/816284/000144530514000438/0001445305-14-000438-index.htm |title=CELGENE CORP /DE/ 2013 Annual Report Form (10-K) |publisher=United States Securities and Exchange Commission |format=XBRL |date=February 13, 2014}}}}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 5.5067 billion (2012)}}}} | net_income = {{unbulleted list|{{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 2.0 billion (2016)}}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 1.4562 billion (2012)}}}} | assets = {{unbulleted list|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 13.3782 billion (2013){{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/816284/000144530514001528/0001445305-14-001528-index.htm |title=CELGENE CORP /DE/ 2014 Q1 Quarterly Report Form (10-Q) |publisher=United States Securities and Exchange Commission |format=XBRL |date=April 29, 2014}}}}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 11.7343 billion (2012)}}}} | equity = {{unbulleted list|{{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 5.5899 billion (2013)}}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 5.6945 billion (2012)}}}} | num_employees = 7,467 (2017){{http://fortune.com/fortune500/celgene/}} | homepage = {{URL|www.celgene.com}} }} '''Celgene Corporation''' is an American biotechnology company that discovers, develops and commercializes medicines for cancer and inflammatory disorders. It is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in [[Summit, New Jersey]]. The company's major product is Revlimid ([[lenalidomide]]), in combination with dexamethasone for the treatment of [[multiple myeloma]] patients. Revlimid is also approved in the United States for the treatment of patients with transfusion-dependent anemia due to Low- or Intermediate-1-risk [[Myelodysplastic syndrome| Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)]] associated with a [[Chromosome 5q deletion syndrome|deletion 5q]] [[cytogenetic abnormality]] with or without additional cytogenetic abnormalities. Revlimid is sold through proprietary risk-management distribution programs to ensure safe and appropriate use of these pharmaceuticals. Vidaza is approved for the treatment of patients with MDS. Celgene Cellular Therapeutics, a subsidiary, is a public [[cord blood bank]]. == History == In 1986, Celgene, originally a unit of the [[Celanese|Celanese Corporation]], was spun off as an independent company following the merger of Celanese Corporation with American Hoechst Corporation. In August 2000, Celgene acquired Signal Pharmaceuticals, Inc., a privately held company that searches for and develops pharmaceuticals that regulate disease-related genes. Signal Pharmaceuticals, Inc. now operates as Celgene Research San Diego, a wholly owned subsidiary of Celgene Corporation. In December 2002, Celgene acquired Anthrogenesis, a privately held New Jersey-based biotherapeutics company and cord blood banking business, which is developing technology for the recovery of stem cells from placental tissues following the completion of full-term successful pregnancies. Anthrogenesis now operates as Celgene Cellular Therapeutics, a wholly owned subsidiary of Celgene. In 2006 Celgene certified McKesson Specialty, a [[specialty pharmacy]], as one of a select group of RevAssist(SM) Program contract pharmacies to launch [[lenalidomide]] (trade name Revlimid). As a [[specialty drugs|specialty drug]], lenalidomide requires special handling and is therefore only available through the RevAssist program, a unique distribution network employing only certified, contracted specialty pharmacies.{{citation |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/celgene-selects-mckesson-specialty-as-a-revassist-program-pharmacy-vendor-to-launch-revlimid-55294122.html |title=Celgene Selects McKesson Specialty as a RevAssist Program Pharmacy Vendor to Launch REVLIMID: McKesson Specialty to Provide Dispensing, Reimbursement and Clinical Services |date=13 February 2006 |accessdate=5 November 2015 |work=PRNewswire |location=Harahan, La.}} In March 2008, Celgene closed its $2.9 billion acquisition of Pharmion Corporation. In December 2009, Celgene announced the acquisition of Gloucester Pharmaceuticals.[http://ir.celgene.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=111960&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1362847 Celgene to Acquire Gloucester Pharmaceuticals] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120713233841/http://ir.celgene.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=111960&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1362847 |date=2012-07-13 }}, Dec. 7, 2009 In 2010 Celgene looked to relocate its UK headquarters from Riverside House in Windsor to a new development Stockley Park, Uxbridge.{{cite news | url=http://www.ukconstructionmagazine.co.uk/online/uk_construction/uk_features/august2011/New%20Head%20Quarters%20for%20Celgene.html | work=UK Construction magazine | title={{sic|hide=y|New Head Q|uarters|expected=Headquarters}} for Celgene - Stockley Park greets new tenant | date=13 October 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030172347/http://www.ukconstructionmagazine.co.uk/online/uk_construction/uk_features/august2011/New%20Head%20Quarters%20for%20Celgene.html | archivedate=30 October 2011 | df= }} In June 2010 Celgene Corporation and Abraxis BioScience Inc. jointly announced the signing of a definitive merger agreement in which Celgene has agreed to acquire Abraxis BioScience.[http://ir.celgene.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=111960&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1442901 Celgene to Acquire Abraxis BioScience Inc.] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120716010035/http://ir.celgene.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=111960&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1442901 |date=2012-07-16 }}, Jun. 30, 2010 In January 2012, Celgene and Avila Therapeutics, Inc., a privately held biotechnology company developing targeted covalent drugs that treat diseases through protein silencing, announced a definitive merger agreement under which Celgene Corporation will acquire Avila Therapeutics, Inc. Under the terms of the merger agreement, Celgene will acquire Avila Therapeutics, Inc. for $350 million in cash, plus up to $195 million for milestones contingent upon the development and regulatory approval of AVL-292, as well as up to $380 million in potential milestone payments contingent upon the development and approval of candidates generated from the Avilomics platform.{{cite news | url=http://www.avilatx.com/news/2012_0126_AvilaCelgene.pdf}} Citing a market capitalization of US$67 billion, and stock appreciation of 107%, Celgene was Forbes Magazine's number 2 ranked drug company of 2013.{{cite news | url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2013/12/31/grading-pharma-in-2013-16-drug-companies-ranked/ |title= Grading Pharma in 2013|publisher=Forbes |date=December 31, 2013 }} In 2014, Celgene and OncoMed Pharmaceuticals entered into a cancer [[Stem cell therapy|stem cell therapeutic]] development agreement encompassing [[demcizumab]] and five other biologics from OncoMed's pipeline.{{cite news | title=OncoMed, Celgene in $3.3B+ Cancer Stem Cell Collaboration | author=Staff | date=January 1, 2014 | page=8 | work=[[Gen. Eng. Biotechnol. News]] | department=Industry Watch }} Also in 2014, [[Sutro Biopharma]] entered into a strategic collaboration and option agreement with Celgene Corporation to discover and develop multispecific antibodies and antibody drug conjugates (ADCs). This new agreement follows the December 2012 collaboration between the two companies and focuses on the field of immuno-oncology.{{cite news | title=Sutro Biopharma and Celgene Corporation Enter Multi-Year Strategic Collaboration and Option to Acquire Agreement| url=http://www.sutrobio.com/sutro-biopharma-and-celgene-corporation-enter-multi-year-strategic-collaboration-and-option-to-acquire-agreement/}} In April 2015, Celgene announced it would commence a collaboration with [[Astrazeneca]], worth $450 million, studying their Phase III immuno-oncology drug candidate MEDI4736.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/astrazeneca-inks-1-8b-in-immuno-oncology-deals-as-q1-profit-dips/81251193/|title=GEN - News Highlights:AstraZeneca Inks $1.8B in Immuno-Oncology Deals as Q1 Profit Dips|work=GEN}} Later in the same month Celgene announced it would acquire [[Quanticel]] for up to $485 million aimed at enhancing their cancer drug pipeline through Quanticels [[epigenetic]] modifier targeting applications.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/celgene-to-acquire-quanticel-for-up-to-485m/81251196/|title=GEN - News Highlights:Celgene to Acquire Quanticel for Up-to-$485M|work=GEN}} In June 2015 Celgene announced it had licensed [[Lycera]]s RORgamma agonist portfolio for up to $105 million and continue to develop its Phase I lead compound [[LYC-30937]] for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. The licensing opportunity gives Celgene the option to acquire Lycera.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/celgene-licenses-lycera-s-immune-modulators-in-up-to-105m-deal/81251366/|title=Celgene Licenses Lycera's Immune Modulators in Up-to-$105M+ Deal|work=GEN}} In July 2015, the company announced it would acquire [[Receptos]] for $7.2 billion in a move to strengthen the company's inflammation and immunology areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/celgene-to-acquire-receptos-for-7-2b/81251504/|title=Celgene to Acquire Receptos for $7.2B|work=GEN}} News of the deal sent Celgene shares up 5.7% in after hours trading. In May 2016, the company announced it would launch partnership with [[Agios Pharmaceuticals]], developing metabolic immuno-oncology therapies. The deal could net more than $1 billion for Agios.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/celgene-agios-launch-1b-metabolic-immuno-oncology-alliance/81252736/|title=Celgene, Agios, Launch $1B+ Metabolic Immuno-oncology Alliance - GEN News Highlights - GEN|work=GEN}} In October, the company acquired [[EngMab AG]] for $600 million.https://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/celgene-600m-engmab-biotech-buy-to-head-into-clinic-next-yearhttps://www.thestreet.com/story/14455526/1/celgene-could-be-bulking-up-very-fast.html In January 2017, the company announced it would acquire [[Delinia]] for $775 million, increasing the company's autoimmune disease therapy offerings.http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/celgene-buys-delinia-for-300m-to-acquire-treg-therapy-for-autoimmune-diseases/81253774 In January 2018, Celgene announced it would acquire [[Impact Biomedicines]] for $7 billion, adding [[fedratinib]], a kinase inhibitor with potential to treat myelofibrosis.https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-impact-biomedicines-m-a-celgene/celgene-to-buy-impact-biomedicines-for-up-to-7-billion-idUKKBN1EW0US In the same month the company announced it would acquire [[Juno Therapeutics]] for $9 billion.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-biotech-m-a/biotech-ma-takes-off-as-sanofi-and-celgene-spend-20-billion-idUSKBN1FB20V ===Company origin and acquisition history=== The following is an illustration of the company's major mergers and acquisitions and historical predecessors (this is not a comprehensive list): {{clade | style=font-size:90%;line-height:110% |thickness=0 |label1= '''Celgene''' |1= {{clade |label1=[[Juno Therapeutics]]

[[Celanese]] in 1986){{Cite news|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/a-year-into-job-celgene-president-and-coo-said-to-retire/81253929|title=A Year into Job, Celgene President and COO Said to Retire|last=|date=February 24, 2017|access-date=February 25, 2017|work=[[Gen. Eng. Biotechnol. News|Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News]]}} Bob Hugin was succeeded in the CEO role by Mark Alles. At the same time, Jacqualyn Fouse was named as the company's [[President (corporate title)|president]] and [[Chief operating officer|COO]]; Fouse had joined the company in 2010 as the [[Chief financial officer|CFO]]. Effective June 30, 2017, Dr. Fouse will purportedly step down and be succeeded by Scott Smith, president of the company's Global Inflammation & Immunology Franchise, who joined the company in 2008. Dr. Fouse has been voted out by the board of directors on 2 April, 2018. == Finances == For the fiscal year 2017, Celgene reported earnings of US$2.539 billion, with an annual revenue of US$13,003 billion, an increase of 15.8% over the previous fiscal cycle. Celgene's shares traded at over $74 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$51.8 billion in November 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/CELG/celgene/revenue|title=Celgene Revenue 2006-2018 {{!}} CELG|website=www.macrotrends.net|access-date=2018-11-05}} {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" !Year !Revenue
in mil. USD$ !Net income

|1,999 |28,086 |7,132 |- |2017 |13,003 |2,940 |30,141 |7,467 |} == Products == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ; |+ Product Portfolio |- valign="bottom" ! width="10%" |Brand Name ! width="25%" |Drug Name(s) ! width="45%" |Indication ! width="25%" |Date Approved (USA){{cite web | url = http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cder/drugsatfda/ | title = Drugs@FDA: FDA Approved Drug Products | accessdate = 2007-09-03 | publisher = [[Food and Drug Administration]]}} ! width="15%" |Partner |- valign="top" |'''Alkeran''' |[[melphalan]] |palliative treatment of multiple myeloma and for the palliation of non-resectable epithelial carcinoma of the ovary |01-17-1964 |[[GlaxoSmithKline]] |- valign="top" |'''Alkeran''' |[[melphalan hydrochloride]] |the palliative treatment of patients with multiple myeloma for whom oral therapy is not appropriate |11-18-1992 |[[GlaxoSmithKline]] |- valign="top" |- valign="top" | |- valign="top" |'''Thalomid''' |[[thalidomide]] |acute treatment of the cutaneous manifestations of moderate to severe erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) and maintenance therapy for prevention and suppression of the cutaneous manifestations of ENL recurrences |07-16-1998 |   |- valign="top" |'''Thalomid''' |[[thalidomide]] |(in combination with [[dexamethasone]]) treatment of patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma |05-25-2006 | [[GlaxoSmithKline]] |- valign="top" | |- valign="top" |'''Focalin''' |dexmethlyphenidate hydrochloride CII |[[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD) in children and adolescents |11-13-2001 |[[Novartis]] |- valign="top" |'''Focalin XR''' |dexmethlyphenidate hydrochloride CII |[[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD) in children, adolescents and adults |05-26-2005 |[[Novartis]] |- valign="top" | |- valign="top" |'''Vidaza''' |[[azacitidine]] |treatment of patients with [[refractory anemia]], [[chronic myelomonocytic leukemia]] |05-19-2004 |   |- valign="top" | |- valign="top" |'''Revlimid''' |[[lenalidomide]] |transfusion dependent anemia due to low or intermediate-1 risk myelodysplastic syndromes associated with a deletion 5 q cytogenetic abnormality with or without additional cytogenetic abnormalities |12-27-2005 |   |- valign="top" |'''Revlimid''' |[[lenalidomide]] |(in combination with [[dexamethasone]]) treatment of multiple myeloma patients who have received at least one prior therapy |06-29-2006 |   |} === Product-related history === In July 1998, Celgene received approval from the FDA to market Thalomid for the acute treatment of the cutaneous manifestations of moderate to severe ENL. In April 2000, Celgene reached an agreement with Novartis Pharma AG to license d-MPH, Celgene's chirally pure version of RITALIN. The FDA subsequently granted approval to market d-MPH, or Focalin, in November 2001. In December 2005, Celgene received approval from the FDA to market Revlimid for the treatment of patients with transfusion-dependent anemia due to Low- or Intermediate-1-risk MDS associated with a deletion 5q [[cytogenetic abnormality]] with or without additional cytogenetic abnormalities.Focalin XR was later launched by Celgene and Novartis in 2005. In May 2006, Celgene received approval for Thalomid in combination with dexamethasone for the treatment of patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma. In June 2007, Celgene received full marketing authorization for Revlimid in combination with dexamethasone as a treatment for patients with multiple myeloma who have received at least one prior therapy by the European Commission. == Litigation == ===Anti-trust allegations=== In 2009, [[Dr. Reddy]]’s Laboratories requested, and Celgene refused to provide, a samples of Celgene's anticancer drug THALOMID® ([[thalidomide]]). Dr. Reddy's Laboratories sought the material for bioequivalency studies required to bring its own, generic, version of thalidomide to market. In response to the refusal, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories filed a Citizen's Petition with the FDA asking the Agency to adopt procedures that would ensure generic applicants the right to buy sufficient samples to perform bioequivalence testing of drugs that were subject to REMS distribution restrictions. Celgene denied that it had behaved anticompetitively, arguing that the legislative history strongly suggested that Congress considered and rejected a proposed guaranteed access procedure like the one proposed by Dr. Reddy’s. Celgene further argued that requiring innovator companies to sell their products to potential generic competitors would violate its intellectual property rights and subject it to liability risks in the event that patients were harmed in Dr. Reddy's studies. Generic manufacturer Lannett Company initiated antitrust litigation that accused Celgene of using its REMS for THALOMID® ([[thalidomide]]) to violate the anti-monopolization provisions of the Sherman Act. In early 2011, the district court denied Celgene’s motion to dismiss. The case was set for trial beginning in February 2012, but the parties settled before the trial began, thereby postponing further judicial review of antitrust claims premised on alleged abuse of REMS distribution restrictions.{{cite web |last=Botts LLP |first=Baker|title=Life Science Update |url=http://www.bakerbotts.com/file_upload/Update_2012_02LifeSciencesNewsletterBrandedManufacturers.htm#footnote6|publisher=Baker Botts LLP |accessdate=February 28, 2012}} ===Fraud allegations=== In July 2017, Celgene agreed to pay $280 million to government agencies to settle allegations that it caused the submission of false claims or fraudulent claims for non-reimbursable uses of its drugs Revlimid and Thalomid to Medicare and state Medicaid programs.{{cite web |title= Celgene Agrees to Pay $280 Million to Resolve Fraud Allegations Related to Promotion of Cancer Drugs For Uses Not Approved by FDA |publisher=Department of Justice, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Central District of California |date=July 24, 2017 |author=Thom Mrozek |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-cdca/pr/celgene-agrees-pay-280-million-resolve-fraud-allegations-related-promotion-cancer-drugs |accessdate=July 27, 2017}} In its July 2017 10-Q, Celgene disclosed that it resolved the matter in full for $315 million, including fees and expenses.|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/816284/000081628417000009/a2017063010q.htm The case was brought under the [[False Claims Act]] by Beverly Brown, a former Celgene sales representative.{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Katie|title=Celgene to Pay $280 Million to Settle Fraud Suit Over Cancer Drugs|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/health/celgene-to-pay-280-million-to-settle-fraud-suit-over-cancer-drugs.html|work=The New York Times|date=25 July 2017}} == See also == * [[Biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area]] * [[Pharmaceutical industry in Switzerland]] * [[Sutro Biopharma]]{{Portal|Companies}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.celgene.com Official website] {{Finance links | name = Celgene | symbol = CELG | sec_cik = CELG | yahoo = CELG | google = CELG }} {{NASDAQ-100}} [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies established in 1986]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Union County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Summit, New Jersey]] [[Category:1986 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies based in New Jersey]] [[Category:Orphan drug companies]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]] {{Infobox person |name = Charles DeLano Hine |image =Charles DeLano Hine.jpg |imagesize=150px |caption= |birth_name= |birth_date = {{birth date|1867|3|15}} |birth_place = [[Vienna, Virginia]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1927|2|13|1867|3|15}} |death_place = [[New York, New York]] | occupation = [[civil engineer]] | religion = | spouse = Helen Underwood | education =[[United States Military Academy]] | writings = | offices_held = | title = | signature = | website = }} '''Charles DeLano Hine''' (March 15, 1867 – Feb. 13, 1927) was an American civil engineer, lawyer, railway official, and Colonel in the United States Army. He receives academic credit for studying organizations as a separate field, rather than a "smaller sister of sociology.".[[Yehouda Shenhav]]. "[http://people.socsci.tau.ac.il/mu/yshenhav/files/2013/07/From-Chaos-to-Systems.pdf From Chaos to Systems: The Engineering Foundations of Organization Theory, 1879-1932]," in: ''Administrative Science Quarterly,'' Vol. 40, No. 4 (Dec., 1995), pp. 564-565 C.D.L. Hine in ''[[Engineering Magazine]].'' Vol. 42 (1912), p. 481''The Bent of Tau Beta Pi.'' Vol. 8 (1913), p. 6Haridimos Tsoukas, Christian Knudsen (2005). ''The Oxford Handbook of Organization Theory.'' p. 186 == Early and family life== Born in [[Vienna, Virginia]] to former Union veteran Capt. [[Orrin E. Hine]] and his wife Alma, Hine graduated from [[United States Military Academy]], West Point in 1891, and served as a lieutenant in the 6th United States Infantry. He later graduated from [[Cincinnati Law School]].Hine (1909, Foreword) He married Helen Underwood on March 27, 1915. ==Career== Leaving the Army to enter railway service, Hine worked as freight brakeman, switchman, yardmaster, emergency conductor, chief clerk to superintendent, and [[Trainmaster (occupation)|trainmaster]]. When the [[Spanish–American War]] began in 1898 he quit railway service and participated in the Santiago campaign as a major of volunteers. After the war he re-entered railway work, rising to trainmaster and later general superintendent. Subsequently, he did special railway work in various staff positions for both large and small railways in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Hine inspected safety appliances for the [[Interstate Commerce Commission]]. In 1907 Hine assisted in the revising the business methods of the [[United States Department of the Interior|Department of the Interior]] at Washington, D.C. Then he was appointed bankruptcy receiver of the [[Northern Virginia trolleys|Washington, Arlington & Falls Church Electric Railway]]. In 1910, Hine became temporary special representative of [[President Taft]], planning ways to improve the organization and methods of the executive departments of the United States government. Meantime, in July, 1908, he had become special representative of Mr. [[Julius Kruttschnitt]], director of maintenance and operation of the Harriman Lines, and had entered on a study of the needs of the operating organization of those railways and of the means that should be adopted to meet those needs. This report led most of the Harriman Lines to adopt the unit system of organization. On January 15, 1912, Major Hine became vice-president and general manager of the [[Southern Pacific Lines]] in Mexico and the Arizona Eastern, responsible for about 1,600 miles of railway. During [[World War I]], on August 5, 1917, Hine (then living in New York City) was drafted to serve as Colonel of Infantry for New York's National Guard. Hisunit was sent overseas, and participated at [[St. Mihiel]] before the war ended and he was honorably discharged on January 10, 1919.New York, Abstracts of World War I Military Service p. 273, for Charles DeLano Hine ==Death and legacy== Hine died in Manhattan in 1927. After a funeral at [[Saint Thomas Church (Manhattan)|St. Thomas Episcopal Church]] in which pall bearers included the President of the [[Lackawanna Railroad]], [[Orlando Harriman Jr.]] and various distinguished military officers,http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/cdhine.htm he was interred at Arlington National Cemetery, and his widow awarded a pension based on his military service. ==Publications== === ''Modern Organization: An Exposition of the Unit System,'' 1912 === In the 1912 article "The unit system on the Harriman Lines" in the ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'' Hine wrote:
Organization has been termed a smaller sister of sociology, the science of human nature. Industrial organization, including that of transportation and commerce, reflects and typifies in a greater or less degree the sociological development of a people."Engineering Magazine, Vol. 42. Jan. 1912: 481-487.
His series of articles were republished in the 1912 book, entitled "Modern Organization: An Exposition of the Unit System." In this work Hine also stated:
The greatest present need is an antidote for the unwillingness of men to profit by the previous experience of others. It would be amusing, were it not so expensive, to watch the gropings of many corporation officers for methods to test efficiency. Ignorant of fundamental principles, intolerant of outside suggestions, unable to detect the analogy in other undertakings, they repeat the expensive experiments of the past.Charles DeLano Hine. (1912) cited in: Robert Scudder Denham. ''The A-B-C of Cost Engineering.'' Denham Cost-Finding Company, 1919. p. 66
A 1913 review in the ''[[Journal of Accountancy]]'' stated that Hines was "a firm believer in the personal equation in industry, commerce and all departments of business. Basing his argument to a great extent upon the successful operation of the unit system as applied on the so-called "Harriman lines" he goes step by step through the ideal method of management and operation to what he considers the practical solution of the difficulties which he encounters."''The Journal of Accountancy,'' Vol. 15 (1913). p. 76 == Selected publications == * Hine, Charles De Lano. ''[https://archive.org/details/lettersfromoldra00hine Letters from an old railway official, to his son, a division superintendent].'' (1904) * Hine, Charles De Lano. ''[http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/45444 Letters from an Old Railway Official: Second Series. His Son, a General Manager].'' Vol. 2. Simmons-Boardman Publishing Company, 1912. * Hine, Charles De Lano. ''[https://archive.org/details/cu31924032515821 Modern Organization: An Exposition of the Unit System, by Charles De Lano Hine].'' Engineering Magazine Company, 1912. == References == {{reflist|2}} ;Attribution [[File:PD-icon.svg|12px]] This article incorporates [[Copyright status of work by the U.S. government|public domain material]] from: Hine, Charles De Lano. ''Letters from an Old Railway Official: Second Series. His Son, a General Manager.'' Vol. 2. == External links == {{wikisource|Author:Charles DeLano Hine}} * [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/cdhine.htm Charles Delano Hine: Colonel, United States Army] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hine, Charles DeLano}} [[Category:1867 births]] [[Category:1927 deaths]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American civil engineers]] [[Category:American lawyers]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:University of Cincinnati College of Law alumni]]
