page.title: Index of articles related to terms of service and privacy policies

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} This is a list of articles about [[terms of service]] and [[privacy policies]]. These are also called terms of use, and are rules one must agree to, in order to use a service. The articles fall in two main categories: descriptions of terms used for specific companies or products, and descriptions of different kinds of terms in general. Articles on companies vary widely in the amount of detail they give on terms of service. Annotations show what is available in the article on each company, and need to be updated as those articles are improved.
Terms of service are regularly the subject of news articles throughout the English-language press, such as in the US,<ref name="ny14">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/23/upshot/one-third-of-top-websites-restrict-customers-right-to-sue.html |title=One-Third of Top Websites Restrict Customers' Right to Sue |last=Merrill |first=Jeremy B. |date=23 October 2014 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="ny17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/03/technology/uber-greyball-program-evade-authorities.html |title=How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide |last=Isaac |first=Mike |date=3 March 2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="ti12">{{Cite news |url=http://business.time.com/2012/08/28/7-surprising-things-lurking-in-online-terms-of-service-agreements/ |title=7 Surprising Things Lurking in Online 'Terms of Service' Agreements |last=Luckerson |first=Victor |work=Time |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US |issn=0040-781X}}</ref><ref name="wired">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/story/zoe-quinn-crash-override-book-excerpt/ |title=Book Excerpt: Zoë Quinn on the Problem of Terms of Service |last=Quinn |first=Zoe |date=9 September 2017 |work=WIRED |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> UK,<ref name="gu17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/03/terms-of-service-online-contracts-fine-print |title=Click to agree with what? No one reads terms of service, studies confirm |last=Berreby |first=David |date=3 March 2017 |work=the Guardian |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="gu15">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jun/15/i-read-all-the-small-print-on-the-internet |title=I read all the small print on the internet and it made me want to die |last=Hern |first=Alex |date=15 June 2015 |work=The Guardian |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name="in17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/twitter-new-terms-of-service-truth-original-content-tweets-embed-messages-posts-a7929256.html |title=People are terrified about Twitter's new terms of service |last=Griffin |first=Andrew |date=4 September 2017 |work=The Independent |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-GB}}</ref> Africa,<ref name="pu17">{{Cite news |url=http://punchng.com/dealing-with-legal-issues-of-digital-afterlife/ |title=Dealing with legal issues of digital afterlife |last=Okoriekwe |first=Chuks |date=13 July 2017 |work=Punch Newspapers (Nigeria) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="st17">{{Cite news |url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/sci-tech/2017-09-07-if-youre-on-facebook-instagram-or-twitter-read-the-ts-and-cs/ |title=If you're on Facebook‚ Instagram or Twitter‚ read the Ts and Cs |last=GOVENDER |first=SUTHENTIRA |date=7 September 2017 |work=Sunday Times (South Africa) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> India,<ref name="et17">{{Cite news |url=http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/digital/twitters-new-terms-of-service-draw-online-criticism/60374030 |title=Twitter's new terms of service draw online criticism – ET BrandEquity |date=5 September 2017 |work=ET Brand Equity (India) |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en}}</ref> Singapore,<ref name="st16">{{Cite web |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/privacy-watchdog-seeks-clarification-on-whatsapps-new-terms |title=Privacy watchdog seeks clarification on WhatsApp's new terms |last=Leow |first=Annabeth |date=29 August 2016 |website=The Straits Times |language=en |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> and Australia.<ref name="smh17">{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/web-culture/teens-finally-understand-rights-after-lawyer-translates-instagram-terms-into-plain-english-20170108-gtny6d.html |title=Teens finally understand rights after lawyer translates Instagram terms into plain English |last=Wang |first=Amy B. |date=9 January 2017 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="smh16">{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/when-you-cant-find-the-fine-print-or-read-it-20160328-gnsqzg.html |title=Never read the terms and conditions? You're not alone |last=Feldman |first=Noah |date=29 March 2016 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |access-date=2017-09-11 |language=en-US}}</ref> Terms of service are also addressed in a widely reviewed documentary,<ref name="imdb">{{Cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2084953/externalreviews |title=Terms and Conditions May Apply (2013)-External Reviews |website=IMDB |access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> academic research,<ref name="fies16">{{Cite paper |last=Fiesler |first=Casey; Cliff Lampe; Amy S. Bruckman |date=2016 |title=Reality and Perception of Copyright Terms of Service for Online Content Creation |url=https://dl.acm.org/ft_gateway.cfm?id=2819931&type=pdf |via=CSCW '16: Proceedings of the 19th ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing,}}</ref><ref name="earp05">{{Cite journal |last=Earp |first=J. B. |last2=Anton |first2=A. I. |last3=Aiman-Smith |first3=L. |last4=Stufflebeam |first4=W. H. |date=May 2005 |title=Examining Internet privacy policies within the context of user privacy values |url=http://www.truststc.org/wise/articles2009/article3.pdf |journal=IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management |volume=52 |issue=2 |pages=227–237 |doi=10.1109/tem.2005.844927 |issn=0018-9391}}</ref><ref name="magi10">{{Cite journal |last=Magi |first=Trina |title=A Content Analysis of Library Vendor Privacy Policies: Do They Meet Our Standards? |url=http://scholarworks.uvm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1005&context=libfacpub |journal=College & Research Libraries |volume=71 |pages=254–272 |via=University of Vermont}}</ref><ref name="sath17">{{Cite paper |last=Sathyendra |first=Kanthashree Mysore, Shomir Wilson, Florian Schaub, Sebastian Zimmeck, Norman Sadeh |date=7 September 2017 |title=Identifying the Provision of Choices in Privacy Policy Text |url=http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/D17-1293 |journal=Proceedings of the 2017 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing |volume=2017 |pages=2764–2769 |via=Association for Computational Linguistics and Carnegie Mellon University}}</ref> and legal research.<ref name="reid14">{{Cite journal |last=Reidenberg |first=Joel |last2=Travis |first2=Breaux, |last3=Faith |first3=Carnor, Lorrie |last4=Brian |first4=French, |date=2014 |title=Disagreeable Privacy Policies: Mismatches Between Meaning and Users’ Understanding |url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2053&context=btlj |journal=Berkeley Technology Law Journal |language=en |volume=30 |issue=1 |doi=10.15779/z384k33 |issn=1086-3818}}</ref><ref name="Klass17">{{Cite paper |last=Klass |first=Gregory |date=8 September 2017 |title=A Critical Assessment of the Empiricism in the Restatement of Consumer Contract Law |url=http://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3005&context=facpub |via=Georgetown University Law School and SSRN}}</ref>
==Articles which describe specific companies' terms of service==
===Social media=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Privacy concerns with social networking services]] – Partially compares privacy policies, data retention, geo-tagging, data releases *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of Q&A sites]] – Compares topics allowed, copyright, and licensing of user contributions *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death *[[Facebook#Privacy|Facebook]] Addresses privacy settings and enforcement *[[Instagram#Controversy|Instagram]] Partly addresses commercial re-use of members' posts, and [[Privacy concerns with social networking services#Instagram|geo-tagging]] *[[Pinterest#User data|Pinterest]] Addresses sales of user data and tracking of users on other websites which have a Pinterest button *[[Tencent#Anti-malware software cheating allegations|Tencent]] Partly addresses user security *[[Twitter#Privacy and security|Twitter]] Addresses privacy, data dissemination, security breaches, legal jurisdiction, deletion to comply with national laws and survivors' requests
===Search engines=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Internet privacy#Privacy focused search engines.2Fbrowsers|Privacy-focused search engines/browsers]] – Partially compares location of servers and hiding IP addresses *[[DuckDuckGo#Overview|DuckDuckGo]] Addresses lack of tracking *[[Privacy concerns regarding Google|Google]] Addresses privacy and [[Indemnity#Without negotiations|indemnification]]
===Browsers=== *[[Comodo Dragon#Comodo license and tracking|Comodo Dragon]] Addresses arbitration, tracking, disclosures, liability, and use of the information for advertising *[[Google Chrome#User tracking|Google Chrome]] Addresses tracking of users, and [[Google Chrome#Security|insecurity]] with VPNs *[[Safari (web browser)#License|Safari]] Addresses tracking, disclaimers, and disclosing unique device identifiers "for any purpose"
===Transport=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Credit card damage waivers]] – Compares credit cards' limits on rental car damages *'''Comparison: '''[[Diminution in value#Car accidents|Diminution in value]] – Compares rental car companies' terms about charging for diminution in value *Air passengers and freight [[Montreal Convention]] 119 states and the EU; [[Warsaw Convention]] 152 states *Road freight: [[CMR Convention]] Europe and Asia; [[Uniform Bill of Lading Act]] USA *Sea freight [[Hague–Visby Rules]] applied in US by the [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act]]; newer are [[Hamburg Rules]] and [[Rotterdam Rules]] *[[CIV (rail travel)|Trains in Europe (CIV)]] Partly addresses guarantee of arrival and connections, baggage, compensation *Trains in UK [[National Rail Conditions of Travel]] Addresses compensation for delays; links to other issues *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Lyft]] Addresses indemnification (user payment of company's legal bills) *[[Contract of carriage#Air travel|Southwest Airlines]] Partly addresses difficulties beyond the airline's control *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Uber]] Addresses indemnification (user payment of company's legal bills)
===Credit cards=== *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|American Express]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Discover]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|Mastercard]] Addresses limits on rental car damages *[[Visa Inc.#Operating regulations|Visa]] Partly addresses terms imposed on merchants, and [[Damage waiver#Credit card coverage of damage waiver|limits]] on rental car damages
===Email=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death
===Utility software=== *[[CCleaner#Licence|CCleaner]] Addresses tracking of users and their software, matching with outside sources of information, use of the information for advertising, data retention, liability *[[GeForce#License|GeForce]] (graphics processing units from Nvidia) Addresses liability, and user data provided to Nvidia, to social media and to advertisers *[[Malwarebytes#License and Privacy|Malwarebytes]] Addresses arbitration, tracking of users and all software they run, their clickstreams, locations, data retention, and use of the information for advertising *[[Microsoft account#History|Microsoft account]] (formerly Passport or Live ID) Partly addresses privacy and allegations of deceptive practices
===Other software=== *'''Comparison: '''[[List of commercial software with available source code]] – Compares copyright, open source, copyright licensing *'''Comparison: '''[[List of commercial video games with available source code]] – Compares copyright licensing
===Online file storage and hosting=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of file hosting services]] - Compares limits on size, bandwidth, expiration *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of online backup services]] - Compares limits on size, bandwidth, server locations, security key management *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free and open-source software licenses]] *'''Comparison: '''[[Death and the Internet]] - Compares rules on access after death *[[Amazon Drive#Limitations|Amazon Drive]] Addresses file sizes and commercial use *[[Baidu Wangpan#Controversy|Baidu Wangpan]] Partly addresses country of storage *[[Dropbox (service)#Privacy and security concerns|Dropbox]] Partly addresses privacy, ownership of data and deletion *[[Google Drive#Ownership and licensing|Google Drive]] Partly addresses privacy and intellectual property *[[ICloud#Privacy|ICloud]] Partly addresses encryption *[[OneDrive#Privacy concerns|OneDrive]] Partly addresses privacy and usage prohibitions *[[SpiderOak#Main features|SpiderOak]] Partly addresses encryption *[[SecureSafe#Data inheritance|SecureSafe]] Addresses digital inheritance *[[Tresorit#Technology|Tresorit]] Addresses encryption
===Website hosts=== *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free blog hosting services]] – Compares limits on size, bandwidth, e-commerce *'''Comparison: '''[[Comparison of free web hosting services]] – Compares use of ads, archiving, and limits on size, bandwidth, e-commerce, scripting *[[Google Sites#Limitations|Google Sites]] Addresses limits on file sizes, e-commerce, scripting, countries *[[Jimdo#Service|Jimdo]] Addresses limits on e-commerce, languages, location of data storage *[[Tripod.com#Services|Tripod]] Addresses storage, e-commerce, scripting *[[Weebly]] Partly addresses storage, e-commerce *[[Wix.com]] Partly addressed e-commerce *[[WordPress.com]] Partly addresses ads, paid upgrades *[[Yola (webhost)#Features|Yola]] Partly addresses limits on storage, web pages
===Broad comparisons across categories=== *[[Death and the Internet#By website|Death and the Internet]] – Compares terms on retention and access after an account holder dies *[[Indemnity#Without negotiations|Indemnity]] – requirements that users pay companies' legal bills
==Articles which discuss terms of service in general== *[[Acceptable use policy]] *[[Click wrap]] *[[Contract of carriage]] *[[Community standards]] *[[Disclaimer]] *[[Email privacy]] *[[End-user license agreement]] *[[Free license]] *[[Free software license]] *[[Free web hosting service]] *[[Internet privacy]] *[[License compatibility]] *[[Multi-licensing]] *[[Open-source license]] *[[Privacy concerns with social networking services]] *[[Privacy policy]] *[[Proprietary software]] *[[Public domain equivalent license]] *[[Service-level agreement]] *[[Shrink wrap contract]] *[[Site license]] *[[Software license]] *[[Standard form contract]] *[[Terms and Conditions May Apply]] *[[Terms of service]] *[[Terms of Service; Didn't Read]] *[[Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977]]

{{primary sources|date=November 2016}}
'''ICMA''' (International City/County Management Association) (originally International City Managers' Association)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://etext.ku.edu/view?docId=ksrlead/ksrl.kc.internationalcitycounty.xml;route=ksrlead;brand=ksrlead;query= |title= Guide to the ICMA Collection - International City/County Management Association records, 1900-2010 |publisher= University of Kansas Libraries |date= 2010 |accessdate= June 2016}}</ref> is an association representing professionals in [[local government]] management. It is based in [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States|USA]].
Founded in 1914 as the International City Managers Association, ICMA provides education and networking opportunities for its members, and offers the Credentialed Manager program to offer professional [[credential]]ing to [[city manager|city and county executive managers]]. It also conducts research, provides technical assistance and training, and promotes professional local government management.<ref name="icma">{{cite web|url=http://icma.org/main/bc.asp?bcid=60&hsid=1&ssid1=17|title=About ICMA|accessdate=2008-12-13}}</ref>
The ICMA Voluntary Credentialing Program recognizes professional local government managers qualified by a combination of education and experience, adherence to high standards of integrity, and an assessed commitment to lifelong learning and professional development. Managers are recognized by ICMA through a peer review credentialing process, and this self-directed program offers an opportunity for interested ICMA members to quantify the unique expertise they bring to their communities. The program also assists ICMA members in focusing and reflecting upon their lifelong professional development experience. Members who participate in the program may earn the designation of ICMA Credentialed Manager granted by the ICMA Executive Board.
The ICMA is considered part of the '[[Big Seven (United States)|Big Seven]]', a group of organisations that represent local and state government in the United States.
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.icma.org/ International City/County Management Association]

page.title: International Federation of Freight Forwarders Associations

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category International business organisations to [[:Category:International business organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=November 2009}} {{use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{use British English|date=May 2014|reason=at May 2014, appeared to be predominant style}} {{coord missing|Switzerland}} {{infobox organization | name = International Federation of Freight Forwarders Associations
({{lang-fr|Fédération Internationale des Associations de Transitaires et Assimilés}}) | image = [[File:Fédération Internationale des Associations de Transitaires et Assimilés (logo).svg|right|200px]] | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | abbreviation = FIATA | motto = | formation = {{Start date and age|1926|5|31|df=yes}} (in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]) | founder = | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | status = | purpose = | professional_title = | headquarters = [[Glattbrugg]], [[Switzerland]]. | location = | coords = | region_served = | services = | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | slogan = | website = {{URL|fiata.com}} }} The '''International Federation of Freight Forwarders Associations''' (or '''FIATA''', {{lang-fr|Fédération Internationale des Associations de Transitaires et Assimilés}}) is a [[non-governmental organization]] representing 40,000 forwarding and logistics companies, employing 8 to 10 million people in 150 countries. ==History and organization== It was founded in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], on 31 May 1926. FIATA has consultative status with the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] (ECOSOC) (''inter alia'' [[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe|ECE]], [[ESCAP]], [[ESCWA]]), the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD), and the [[United Nations Commission on International Trade Law]] (UNCITRAL). It is recognised as representing the [[freight forwarding|freight-forwarding]] industry by many other governmental organisations, governmental authorities, private international organisations in the field of transport such as the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] (ICC), the [[International Air Transport Association]] (IATA), the [[International Union of Railways]] (UIC), the [[International Road and Transport Union]] (IRU), the [[World Customs Organization]] (WCO), the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO), etc. ==FIATA Foundation== Just before the World Congress 2001 in [[Cancún]], [[Quintana Roo]], [[Mexico]], and on the occasion of FIATA's 75th anniversary, the presidency of FIATA decided to mark this particular event with the creation of the FIATA Foundation Vocational Training, an institution which aims to assist associations in less-privileged countries to build up and enhance professional skill in the industry. The management committee of the foundation coordinates the fundraising activities, evaluates the applications for funds and helps the associations on the implementation of Training projects. ==Documents== FIATA has created several documents and forms to establish a uniform standard for use by freight forwarders worldwide. The documents are easily distinguishable as each has a distinctive colour and carries the FIATA logo which can be seen at the head of this page. {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * FCR: Forwarders Certificate of Receipt * FCT: Forwarders Certificate of Transport * FWR: FIATA [[Warehouse]] Receipt * FBL: FIATA [[Bill of Lading]] (negotiable [[Multimodal transport|Multimodal]] Transport) * FWB: FIATA [[Waybill]] (non-negotiable Multimodal Transport) * SDT: Shippers Declaration for the Transport (of [[Dangerous Goods]]) * SIC: Shippers Intermodal Weight Certificate * FFI: FIATA Forwarding Instructions {{div col end}} ==Headquarters== The organisation is headquartered in [[Glattbrugg]], [[Switzerland]].Staff (undated). [http://www.fiata.com/index.php?id=98 "About FIATA > Contact"]. International Federation of Freight Forwarders Associations. Retrieved 10 May 2013. ==See also== {{portal|Business and economics|Transport}} * [[Moving company]] * [[HAFFA|Hong Kong Association of Freight Forwarding & Logistics]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{URL|fiata.com}}, the organisation's official website [[Category:1920s establishments in Austria]] [[Category:Canton of Zürich]] [[Category:International business organizations]] [[Category:Freight forwarders associations]] [[Category:International organisations based in Switzerland]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1926]] [[az:FIATA]] [[cs:FIATA]] [[de:FIATA]] [[ru:Международная федерация экспедиторских ассоциаций]] [[sk:Medzinárodná federácia zasielateľských združení]] [[zh:国际货运代理协会联合会]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2015}}
{{Infobox person|name = Karen Behnke|image = Karen Behnke.jpg{{!}}border|birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1957}}|residence = [[San Anselmo, CA]], U.S.|occupation = businessperson, entrepreneur|alma_mater = [[Western Michigan University]]}}'''Karen Behnke''' (born 1957) is a businessperson and entrepreneur in the Healthy Lifestyles sector of business. Behnke's current company is Juice Beauty, an "organic eco-chic beauty products company".<ref name="Juice Beauty">{{cite web|title=Karen Behnke, Juice Beauty Founder discusses Malic Acid|url=http://www.juicebeauty.com/2013/08/26/karen-behnke-juice-beauty-founder-discusses-malic-acid/|website=Juice Beauty|publisher=Juice Beauty|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Karen Behnke - San Francisco Business Times|url = http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2006/07/03/smallb5.html|website = San Francisco Business Times|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> Juice Beauty is specialized in making skincare, makeup, and haircare made with organic ingredients.<ref name=WWD>{{cite web|last1=Cyk|first1=Jayme|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Invests in Juice Beauty|url=http://wwd.com/beauty-industry-news/people/gwyneth-paltrows-invests-in-juice-beauty-8234652/|website=WWD|publisher=Fairchild Publishing|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
==Early career== From 1983 to 1996, Behnke founded PacifiCare Wellness Company (formerly known as Execu-Fit Health Programs) in [[San Francisco]], one of the first corporate wellness companies in the country. The company delivered worksite medical fitness screenings, health risk appraisals, and fitness programs, for major corporations. The Wellness Company grew to provide services to over 2 million members in six states staffed with 300 healthcare professional employees. Behnke sold the company to PacifiCare Health Systems (now [[United Healthcare]]) in 1991 and became the parent company’s second female executive during a five-year growth phase from $1 to $5 billion in revenue.<ref name=MyWMU>{{cite web|title=Eco Chic|url=http://www.mywmu.com/s/1428/gid2/index.aspx?sid=1428&gid=2&calcid=3680&calpgid=906&pgid=252&ecid=1948&crid=0|website=MyWMU|publisher=Western Michigan University|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
From 1996-2003, Behnke led the Healthy Lifestyles investment strategy for a private equity firm that was the majority shareholder of [[24 Hour Fitness]]. Behnke joined the Board of Directors and was an Operating Executive for 24 Hour Fitness, during a seven-year growth period, from $75 mm to over $1 billion in revenue.
==Accomplishments== Behnke completed Harvard/MIT’s multi-year Executive Business Summer School “Giants” program, graduated from [[Western Michigan University]], and has received many awards throughout her career including (2011) Woman Entrepreneur of the Year;<ref name="MyWMU"/> the “Top EcoLeader” named by [[Glamour Magazine]] for their anniversary special (2009);<ref name=Glamour>{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Brittany|title=Meet Your 70 Eco Heroes|url=http://www.glamour.com/magazine/2009/03/meet-your-70-eco-heroes|website=Glamour|publisher=Condé Nast.|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> San Francisco Woman Entrepreneur of the Year Award (1987);<ref name=wattpad>{{cite web|title=Exactly why Natural Beauty Products is incredible|url=http://www.wattpad.com/38526075-exactly-why-natural-beauty-products-is-incredible|website=wattpad|publisher=WP Technology|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> the San Francisco Examiner’s Top 39 Movers and Shakers under the age of 39;<ref name="wattpad"/> and the WMU Distinguished Alumni Award.<ref name="MyWMU"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Behnke, Karen}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Western Michigan University alumni]] [[Category:People from San Anselmo, California]] [[Category:1957 births]]

{{About-distinguish2|a businessman born in 1948|his cousin Lenny (born 1953), described at [[Recanati winery]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Leon Recanati | image =Leon Recanati - ליאון רקנאטי-1293.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1948|05|10}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | nationality = Israel | education = | occupation = businessman and philanthropist | known_for = co-chairman of IDB Holding | networth = | spouse = | parents = Mathilda Carasso
Daniel Recanati | children = 3 | relatives = [[Leon Yehuda Recanati]] (paternal grandfather)
[[Raphael Recanati]] (paternal uncle)
[[Michael Recanati]] (first cousin)
[[Thomas Kaplan]] (Son in law) [[Avraham Rakanti]] (great uncle) | website = }} '''Leon Recanati''' ({{lang-he-n|ליאון רקנאטי}}; born May 10, 1948) is an [[Israelis|Israeli]] businessman and philanthropist. ==Biography== Lean Recanati is the son of Mathilda and Daniel Recanati.[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/Leon_Recanati.html Jewish Virtual Library: "Leon Recanati"] retrieved May 12, 2013 His father served as CEO of the [[Israel Discount Bank]] and along with his brothers, established the IDB Holding Corporation.{{cite news | author = | title =Leon Yehuda Recanati | publisher =Tel Aviv University/Recanati Business School | date= | url =http://recanati-bs.tau.ac.il/Eng/?CategoryID=308&ArticleID=461| accessdate=2013-02-18}} After completing his military service, Recanati earned a B.A. in economics and an M.B.A. at [[Hebrew University]] in Jerusalem.Recanati is married to Shula Recanati. They have a daughter together.[http://www.grg.co.il/management_shula_recanati.html Glen Rock Israel website: Management - Dr. Shula Recanati] retrieved May 12, 2013 He has two children with his first wife Mira. Their daughter Dafna is married to American philanthropist and investor [[Thomas Kaplan]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/nyregion/10routine.html|title=Coffee for Me, Worms for Her|author=Robin Finn|date=10 January 2010|website=The New York Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/thomas-kaplan/|title=Thomas Kaplan|author=|date=|website=forbes.com}} ==Business career== In 1971, he worked for the Israel Discount Bank – which was founded by his grandfather, [[Leon Yehuda Recanati]]. In 1979, he was appointed deputy CEO with responsibility for all branches and marketing. He largely escaped the scandal of the [[1983 Israel bank stock crisis]].{{cite news|last1=Lipson|first1=Nathan|title=The Losses of Leon Recanati|url=https://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/the-losses-of-leon-recanati-1.259224|accessdate=24 December 2017|publisher=Haaretz|date=October 12, 2008}} In 1986, he transferred to IDB Holding, the investment side of the family business where he rotated through various chairmanships at [[Shufersal|Supersol]], [[Delek]] and Clal, and later served as co-CEO and co-chairman of IDB Holding. In May 2003, the family sold IDB Holding to [[Nochi Dankner]][http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/the-losses-of-leon-recanati-1.259224 Haaretz: "The losses of Leon Recanati - He had it all: money, prestige - but the scion of the banking family wanted more" By Nathan Lipson] December 10, 2008 and divided its assets. With his share, Recanati established Glenrock, an investment company, which he ran with his wife Shula Recanati and Ziv Kop. It has three divisions: ''GlenRock America'' assists Israeli businesses in entering the American market and also serves as a conduit for American investors to invest in Israel (headed by Larry Graev); ''GlenRock Israel'' invests in local technology companies; and ''GlenRock Italy'' advises Israeli businesses in penetrating the Italian market and serves as a bridge for Italian investors interested in investing in Israel (headed by Rony Benatof). In 2007, he purchased a 50.4% stake (73% total with two minority partners) in the Gmul Investment Company for NIS 600 million more than twice its market capitalization. Gmul had stakes in real estate, hotels, investments, and automotive. It was founded in 1950 by Bank Hapoalim, the Histadrut labor federation and several pension funds then sold to the brothers Jules and Eddy Trump, who listed it on the [[Tel Aviv Stock Exchange]], and then sold in October 2003 to Eyal Yona and Amnon Barzilay. Performance at Gmul deteriorated. Recanati stated: "At this point I can say that buying control of Gmul was the worst deal I have ever made... I cannot invest any more in Gmul, but I hope that we can all work together to find a solution and reach a fair, mutually agreed-upon arrangement."[http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/recanati-buying-gmul-was-the-worst-deal-in-my-life-1.259223 Haaretz: "Recanati: 'Buying Gmul was the worst deal in my life' -Leumi is demanding immediate repayment of NIS 5 million in loans" By Michael Rochvarger and Yuval Maoz] December 10, 2008 In October 2011, he sold half of his 50.4% investment in Gmul to Itzhak Gvilli for NIS 20 million.[http://www.haaretz.com/business/cutting-his-losses-recanati-sells-half-his-stake-in-gmul-1.388460 Haaretz: "Recanati Cutting his losses / Recanati sells half his stake in Gmul - Leon Recanati, through his privately owned company Legov, sells 25.2% of the company's stock, representing half his 50.4% stake, along with a share in control to CPA Itzhak Gvilli for up to NIS 20 million" By Michael Rochvarger] October 6, 2011 He resigned as chairman of Gmul in July 2012.[http://in.reuters.com/finance/stocks/GMUL.TA/key-developments/article/2594497 Reuters: GMUL Investment Company Ltd Announces Resignation of Chairman, Mr. Leon Recanati] July 30, 2012 ==Philanthropy== Recanati serves as vice chairman of the Israel Cancer Association. He has served as chairman of [[Tel Aviv University]]'s Development Committee and he also is involved with the [[Israel Museum]] and the [[Tel Aviv Museum]]. Recanati established the Tapuah program in Israel which established 48 centers in disadvantaged areas and Bedouin, Druze and Arab villages where basic computer and internet training is provided. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Recanati, Leon}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hebrew University of Jerusalem alumni]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli people of Greek-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israeli philanthropists]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Recanati family]]

A '''line splice''' is a special type of connection of [[electrical cable]]s ('''electrical splice''') or [[optical fiber]]s ('''optical splice''') in [[telecommunication technology]].
Splices are often housed in [[Sleeve (construction)|sleeve]]s to protect against external influences.
=={{anchor|Electrical splice}}Splicing of copper wires== [[Image:Spleiß Ader.png|thumb|Splice site of a copper wire.]] [[Image:Kabelmuffe Blei 600 635.jpg|thumb|Cable [[Sleeve (construction)|sleeve]] (lead sleeve) for connecting paper-insulated wires]] [[Image:Kabelmuffe Blei2 600 565.jpg|thumb|Insulating sleeves]]
The splicing of copper wires happens in the following steps:
* The cores are laid one above the other at the junction. * The wires are wrapped two to three times around each other ([[Transposition (telecommunications)|twisting]]). * The core insulation is removed. * The bare veins on a length of about 3 cm "strangle" or "twist". In some cases, the strangulation is soldered. * To isolate the splice, an insulating sleeve made of paper or plastic is pushed over it.
The splicing of copper wires is mainly used on paper insulated wires.
LSA techniques (LSA: soldering, screwing and stripping free) are used to connect copper wires, making the copper wires faster and easier to connect. LSA techniques include:
* Wire connection sleeves (AVH = Adernverbindungshülsen) and other crimp connectors. The two wires to be connected are inserted into the AVH without being stripped, which is then compressed with special pliers. The about 2 cm long AVH consist of contact, pressure and insulation. * For wire connection strips (AVL = Adernverbindungsleisten) several pairs of wires (10 = AVL10 or 20 = AVL20) are inserted, the strip is then closed with a lid and pressed together with a hydraulic press, which ensures the connection.
=={{anchor|Optical splice}}Splicing of glass fibers==
[[Image:Www.lwl-glasfaser-spleissen.de.jpg|thumb|Splicing of glass fibers by thermal [[fusion splice]]. Fiber optic cable sleeve]] [[Image:Fiber Splice.jpg|thumb|Fiber optic cable splicer]]
[[Fiber-optic cable]]s are spliced using a special arc-splicer, with installation cables connected at their ends to respective "pigtails" - short individual fibers with [[fiber-optic connector]]s at one end. The splicer precisely adjusts the light-guiding cores of the two ends of the glass fibers to be spliced. The adjustment is done fully automatically in modern devices, whereas in older models this is carried out manually by means of micrometer screws and microscope. An experienced splicer can precisely position the fiber ends within a few seconds. Subsequently, the fibers are fused together (welded) with an electric arc. Since no additional material is added, such as gas welding or soldering, this is called a "[[fusion splice]]".
Depending on the quality of the splicing process, attenuation values at the splice points are achieved by 0.3 dB, with good splices also below 0.02 dB. For newer generation devices, alignment is done automatically by motors. Here one differentiates core and jacket centering. At core centering (usually [[single-mode fiber]]s), the fiber cores are aligned. A possible core offset with respect to the jacket is corrected. In the jacket centering (usually in multimode fibers), the fibers are adjusted to each other by means of electronic image processing in front of the splice.
When working with good equipment, the damping value is according to experience at max. 0.1 dB. Measurements are made by means of special measuring devices including [[optical time-domain reflectometry]] (OTDR). A good splice should have an attenuation of less than 0.3 dB over the entire distance. Finished fiber optic splices are housed in splice boxes.
One differentiates:<ref name="R1"/>
* Fusion splice * Adhesive splicing * Crimp splice or NENP (no-epoxy no-polish), mechanical splice
==See also== * [[Fusion splice]] * [[Mechanical splice]]
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="R1">{{cite web |title=Crimp splice |website=itwissen.info |url=https://www.itwissen.info/Crimp-Spleiss-crimp-splice.html |access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> }} * {{cite book |author-first=Andrew D. |author-last=Yablonx |title=Optical fiber fusion splicing |publisher=Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, New York |date=2005 |isbn=978-3-540-23104-2}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} [[File:Martin F. Allen.jpg|thumb|Martin F. Allen]] '''Martin Fletcher Allen''' (November 28, 1842 – May 24, 1927) was a [[Vermont]] banker, businessman, farmer and politician who served one term as [[List of Lieutenant Governors of Vermont|Lieutenant Governor]].
==Early life== Martin Fletcher Allen was born in [[Ferrisburgh, Vermont|North Ferrisburgh, Vermont]] on November 28, 1842. He attended [[Eastman Business College]] in [[Poughkeepsie, New York]] and became a merchant and store owner. Allen was also involved in several other businesses, including banking, farms and a grist mill, in addition serving as North Ferrisburg's [[Postmaster]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=3wjt3eoLPF4C&pg=PA71&dq=%22martin+f+allen%22+vermont&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hpr-Ttq-Lung0QHLj72WAg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22martin%20f%20allen%22%20vermont&f=false Genealogical and Family History of the State of Vermont], edited by Hiram Carleton, 1903, pages 71 to 72</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=TaITAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA33&dq=martin+allen+ferrisburgh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o5v-TtKmOaXa0QHXpejgDw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=martin%20allen%20ferrisburgh&f=false Who's Who in New England], published by A. N. Marquis, Chicago, Volume 1, 1909, page 33</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hY8eAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA57&dq=%22martin+fletcher+allen%22+ferrisburg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0aP-TpCQC9CTtwex7ZicCA&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22martin%20fletcher%20allen%22%20ferrisburg&f=false Biography, Martin F. Allen], The Vermonter magazine, November 1900, page 57</ref><ref>Vermont Legislative Directory, published by Vermont Secretary of State, 1900, page 373</ref>
==Political involvement== A Republican, Allen served in the [[Vermont House of Representatives]] from 1882 to 1883 and the [[Vermont Senate]] from 1890 to 1891. He was elected Vermont's Lieutenant Governor in 1900 and served until 1902.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Uo8eAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA230&dq=martin+allen+ferrisburgh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o5v-TtKmOaXa0QHXpejgDw&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=martin%20allen%20ferrisburgh&f=false Magazine article, Republican nominees], The Vermonter magazine, July 1900, page 230</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EeV6r-D7w9oC&pg=PA331&dq=martin+allen+ferrisburgh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eJz-Tq6GIefk0QH5-tCdCw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=martin%20allen%20ferrisburgh&f=false Vermont: The Green Mountain State], by Walter Hill Crockett, Volume 4, 1921, page 331</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927011635/http://vermont-archives.org/govhistory/elect/results1/pdf/stoff2ltgov.pdf General Election results, Lieutenant Governor, 1813–2008], Office of the Vermont Secretary of State, State Archives and Records Administration, 2008, page 15</ref>
==Criminal trial== In May 1901 Allen was one of several officers of the Farmers' National Bank who were arrested and accused of being complicit in embezzlement by the bank's Cashier. The officers of the bank were tried in 1902 and found not guilty, while the Cashier was convicted and sentenced to seven years in prison.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1901/05/28/118464813.pdf Newspaper article, Vermont Official Arrested], New York Times, May 28, 1901</ref><ref>[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/771287672.html?dids=771287672:771287672&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+28%2C+1901&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=ARREST+HIGH+OFFICIAL&pqatl=google Arrest High Official: Lieut. Gov. Allen of Vermont Under Indictment], Chicago Tribune, May 28, 1901</ref><ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1902/04/27/118469004.pdf Newspaper article, Bank Wrecker Sentenced: Clerk Ketchum of Vergennes (Vt.) Institution Given Seven Years – Lieut. Gov. Allen Acquitted], New York Times, April 27, 1902</ref>
==Retirement and death== After leaving office Allen resumed his business pursuits, remaining active until complications of [[Alzheimer's disease]] caused him to withdraw from active pursuits, after which he lived in retirement in North Ferrisburgh. Allen died in North Ferrisburgh on May 24, 1927. He was buried in North Ferrisburgh Cemetery.<ref>Vermont Death Records, 1909–2008, Record for Martin F. Allen, accessed December 31, 2011</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
{{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before=[[Henry C. Bates]] | title=[[List of lieutenant governors of Vermont|Lieutenant Governor of Vermont]] | years=1900–1902 | after=[[Zed S. Stanton]]}} {{s-end}}

'''Measurement-assisted assembly''' ('''MAA''')<ref>Kayani, A. and J. Jamshidi. Measurement Assisted Assembly For Large Volume Aircraft Wing Structures. in 4th International Conference on Digital Enterprise Technology. 2007. Bath, United Kingdom. p. 426-434</ref> is any method of assembly in which measurements are used to guide assembly processes. Such processes include: * '''Predictive fettling/shimming'''<ref>Kayani, A. and I. Gray, Shim for Arrangement Against a Structural Component and a Method of Making a Shim. 2009, Patent US20080211185 20080916, Airbus UK Ltd</ref> in which component measurements are used to predict gaps and interferences prior to assembly, and these predictions are used to enable a right-first-time assembly * '''Assemble-Measure-Move''' ('''AMM''')<ref>Muelaner, J.E., A. Kayani, O. Martin, and P.G. Maropoulos. Measurement Assisted Assembly and the Roadmap to Part-To-Part Assembly. in 7th International Conference on Digital Enterprise Technology. 2011. Athens, Greece, Available from http://www.muelaner.com/research/MADA/MAA_and_Roadmap_to_Part-To-Part.html</ref> processes where a component is positioned approximately in an assembly, the position of the component is measured and then it is moved towards its specified position. This process may be iterated a number of times before the component is within its specified position, alternatively 'real time' measurements may be used to 'track' the component into location. * '''Active tooling''' is a form of [[Fixture (tool)|assembly fixture]] which does not rely on inherent dimensional stability to provide an accurate location for components but rather uses frequent measurements to facilitate in active compensation. * '''[[Control theory|Closed loop control]]''' of assembly automation in order to improve the accuracy of flexible automation systems such as [[industrial robots]].<ref>Summers, M., Robot Capability Test and Development of Industrial Robot Positioning System for the Aerospace Industry, in AeroTech Congress & Exhibition. 2005, SAE International: Grapevine,Texas. p. 1-13</ref> Measurement-assisted assembly is typically used for large structures such as [[Airframe|aircraft]] and [[Fabrication (metal)|steel fabrications]]. It can be used to improve production rates, reduce reworking and increase flexibility for processes where manual reworking during assembly is required to maintain assembly form and component interface conditions. This type of approach generally offers no advantages where [[Interchangeable parts|part-to-part interchangeability]] can already be achieved.
== Notes and references == <references />
