{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Pierre Casiraghi | image = File:Pierre Casiraghi 2017.jpg | birth_name = Pierre Rainier Stefano Casiraghi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1987|9|5}} | birth_place = [[Princess Grace Hospital Centre]], [[La Colle, Monaco|La Colle]], Monaco | alma_mater = [[Bocconi University]] | occupation = Businessman
[[Majority shareholder]], Engeco S.A. & [[Monacair]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Beatrice Borromeo]]|2015}} | children = 2 | parents = [[Stefano Casiraghi]]
[[Caroline, Princess of Hanover]] | relatives = [[Andrea Casiraghi]] (brother)
[[Charlotte Casiraghi]] (sister)
[[Princess Alexandra of Hanover (born 1999)|Princess Alexandra of Hanover]] (half-sister) }} '''Pierre Rainier Stefano Casiraghi ''' (born 5 September 1987) is the younger son of [[Caroline, Princess of Hanover]], and her second husband, [[Stefano Casiraghi]]. His maternal grandparents were [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco]], and American actress [[Grace Kelly]]. Casiraghi is eighth in the [[line of succession to the Monegasque throne]], following his twin cousins, his mother, brother [[Andrea Casiraghi|Andrea]], nephews [[Alexandre Casiraghi|Alexandre]] and Maximillian Casiraghi, and his niece [[India Casiraghi]]. == Early life and education == Casiraghi was born in 5 September 1987 at [[Princess Grace Hospital Centre]], in [[La Colle, Monaco|La Colle]], [[Monaco]]. He is named after his maternal great-grandfather, [[Prince Pierre, Duke of Valentinois]], his maternal grandfather, [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Prince Rainier III]], and his father. His godparents are his uncle, [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Prince Albert II]], and his aunt by marriage Laura Sabatini Casiraghi, the wife of his uncle Daniele. Casiraghi was three years old at the time of his father's death in a boating accident. He spent his earliest years, after his father's death, living at his mother's farmhouse in the quaint town of [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence]]. He attended a state school in [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence]]. However, after his mother's remarriage to [[Prince Ernst August of Hanover (born 1954)|Ernst August, Prince of Hanover]], the family moved to [[Fontainebleau]], to be nearer to [[Paris]] and [[London]], the latter being where his new stepbrothers lived with their mother. It is assumed that Casiraghi passed the [[French Baccalaureate]] exam in the summer of 2005 since he shortly afterwards began [[university]]. One year later, in fact, he moved to [[Milan]] to begin a three-year undergraduate course in International Economics and Management at [[Bocconi University]].{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2006/settembre/24/figlio_Carolina_Bocconi_come_papa_co_9_060924063.shtml |title=Archivio Corriere della Sera |website=Archiviostorico.corriere.it |date=2016-02-29 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Besides [[French language|French]], he is fluent in [[Italian language|Italian]], [[English language|English]], and knows some [[German language|German]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://us.hellomagazine.com/royalty/2014090520820/pierre-casiraghi-10-facts-birthday/ |title=Pierre Casiraghi: 10 facts about Princess Caroline's son |website=Us.hellomagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} He also plays the [[saxophone]]. ==Humanitarian and business activities== From 30 January to 13 February 2007, Casiraghi accompanied his mother on a [[humanitarian]] tour of Africa.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070519035117/http://www.monaco-consulate.com/Princess_of_Hanover/africa.htm ] They visited [[Niger]], [[Burundi]], the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]], and [[South Africa]] on behalf of Princess Caroline's role as President of [[AMADE Mondiale]]. In June 2009, Casiraghi became the majority shareholder of the Monaco-based construction company Engeco, which his father founded in 1984. His uncle Marco remains in the position of President over Engeco. The acquisition of the majority shares to Casiraghi's name was handled by the [[Milan]]-based legal firm [[Bird & Bird]].{{cite web|url=http://www.twobirds.com/Italian/NEWS/PRESSRELEASES/Pagine/Lo_Studio_Legale_Bird_Bird_Italia_assiste_Pierre_Casiraghi_nell_acquisizione_della_quota_maggioritaria_di_ENGECO_SAM.Aspx |title=News Centre |website=Twobirds.com |date=2013-01-21 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Casiraghi is also the majority shareholder of [[Monacair]].,{{cite web|url=http://www.podcastjournal.net/NOMINATION-DE-PIERRE-CASIRAGHI-COMME-MEMBRE-D-HONNEUR-DE-LA-JEUNE-CHAMBRE-ECONOMIQUE_a7955.html |title=Nomination De Pierre Casiraghi Comme 'Membre D'Honneur' De La Jeune Chambre Economique |website=Podcastjournal.net |date=2011-04-16 |accessdate=2017-03-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.montecarlonews.it/notizie/argomenti/altre-notizie-1/articolo/pierre-casiraghi-membro-onorario-della-jeune-chambre-economique.html |title=Pierre Casiraghi membro onorario della Jeune Chambre Economique - MontecarloNews: notizie su Montecarlo, Monaco, Mentone, Nizza, Antibes, Costa Azzurra |website=Montecarlonews.it |date=2011-04-16 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Casiraghi is on the Management Committee of the [[Yacht Club de Monaco]]. In this capacity, he sponsored the “Sail for a Cause" charity race,{{cite web|url=http://www.monacochannel.mc/Chaines/Yacht-Club-de-Monaco/ACTUS-PHOTOS/Sail-for-a-cause-la-regate-du-caeur2 |title=Sail for a cause : la régate du cœur / ACTUS & PHOTOS / Yacht Club de Monaco / Chaines - MC Channel - Chaines vidéos de Monaco |language=fr |website=Monacochannel.mc |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} a cause which was organized by his cousin Leticia de Massy, using her social network LeSpot.Net to promote it.{{cite web|title=Spirit of Generosity|url=https://www.yacht-club-monaco.mc/en/spirit-of-generosity/|website=Yacht Club de Monaco|accessdate=11 November 2017}} ''Sail for a Cause'' raises money for two charities: the Monaco Collectif Humanitaire and the Maison Notre Dame de Paix in Chad. The former funds surgeries for children around the world;{{cite web|title=50.000 € GATHERED FOR MONACO COLLECTIF HUMANITAIRE THANKS TO "SAIL FOR A CAUSE"|url=http://mch.mc/en/50-000-e-gathered-for-monaco-collectif-humanitaire-thanks-to-sail-for-a-cause/|accessdate=14 November 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114094016/http://mch.mc/en/50-000-e-gathered-for-monaco-collectif-humanitaire-thanks-to-sail-for-a-cause/|archivedate=14 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} the latter helps migrants.{{cite web|title=Chad: assisting migrants and other vulnerable groups|url=https://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/update/2011/chad-update-2011-10-13.htm|website=International Committee of the Red Cross|accessdate=14 November 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801190139/https://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/update/2011/chad-update-2011-10-13.htm|archivedate=1 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} In 2011, Casiraghi was inducted as an honorary member of the ''Jeune Chambre Economique de Monaco'' (JCEM). ==Inshore Racing== Casiraghi is a participant in the sport of [[sailing (sport)|inshore racing]], which differs from offshore racing in that it is done along the coastlines. In January 2014, he was part of the [[Masarati]] team in the Cape2Rio competition. His team completed the journey from [[Cape Town]] to [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio]] in a record 10 days, 11 hours. 29 minutes, and 57 seconds.{{cite web|title=Nautisme: Masterati pulvérise le Record de Cape2Rio en 10 jours et 11 heures|url=http://www.monacomatin.mc/monaco/nautisme-maserati-pulverise-le-record-de-cape2rio-en-10-jours-et-11-heures.1586461.html|website=Monaco Matin|accessdate=14 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125043644/http://www.monacomatin.mc/monaco/nautisme-maserati-pulverise-le-record-de-cape2rio-en-10-jours-et-11-heures.1586461.html|archivedate=25 November 2015|df=dmy-all}} Casiraghi was a crew member of the Monaco Racing Fleet captained by Tommaso Chieffi which was first to cross the finish line in the 2013 edition of the [[Palermo]]-[[Monte Carlo]] Regatta.{{cite web|url=http://en.monacochannel.mc/Channels/Monaco-Info-Les-Reportages/Videos/Pierre-Casiraghi-victorious-in-Palermo-Monte-Carlo-regatta-2013 |title=Pierre Casiraghi victorious in Palermo/Monte-Carlo regatta 2013 / Videos / Monaco Info : Les Reportages / Channels - MC Channel - Video channels of Monaco |website=En.monacochannel.mc |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Casiraghi and the Monaco Racing Fleet also won the 10th edition of the Palmero-Monte Carlo race in August 2014.,{{cite web|author=MyRegioLife |url=http://monacoreporter.com/2014/08/25/pierre-casiraghi-wins-palermo-montecarlo-regatta/ |title=Pierre Casiraghi’s team wins 10th edition of Palermo-Montecarlo regatta |publisher=Monaco Reporter |date=2014-08-25 |accessdate=2017-03-06}}{{cite web|author=servanne sohier |url=http://monacoreporter.com/2014/08/13/palermo-montecarlo-regatta/ |title=Palermo-Montecarlo regatta celebrating 10th anniversary |publisher=Monaco Reporter |date=2014-08-13 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Casiraghi's boat, the ''Esimit Europa 2'', was the winner of the [[Giraglia Rolex Cup]] in June 2014.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140625055234/http://www.monacomatin.mc/monaco/pierre-casiraghi-gagne-la-giraglia-rolex-cup.1789907.html ] Casiraghi is the [[Sea captain#Skipper|skipper]] of Team Malizia, the crew which sails a [[sailing hydrofoil|hydrofoil sailboat]] (also called a foiling catamaran) in the annual GC32 Racing Tour. Team Malizia takes its name from ''Il Malizia'', which means the Cunning, and which was the nickname assigned to Casiraghi's medieval ancestor [[François Grimaldi]].{{cite book|last1=Knightley|first1=Emma|title=Princely Monaco XXI: The House of Grimaldi in the 21st Century|date=29 November 2017|ISBN=9780359058945}} In August 2017, Casiraghi paired with [[Boris Herrmann]] to sail in the [[Fastnet Race]]. Starting at [[Cowes]], moving up to Ireland and then back down to [[Devon]]shire, they finished the race in third place. ==Car Racing== Casiraghi is a fixture in the [[Monte Carlo Rally|Monte-Carlo Historic Rally]], a vintage car race that happens every year in January. However, in May 2014, he competed in a professional car race for the first time at the [[Volkswagen Scirocco R-Cup]] in [[Hockenheim]]. He was a celebrity guest starter in the race, driving car #26, and finished 22nd in the first race and 20th in the second race.{{cite web|url=http://www.volkswagen-motorsport.com/index.php?id=886&L=1 |title=WRC - Rallycross - Formula 3 |publisher=Volkswagen Motorsport |date=1966-07-11 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} He said he was encouraged to do the race by family friend and racing legend [[Jacky Ickx]].{{cite web|url=http://www.motoroids.com/news/volkswagen-motorsport-pierre-casiraghi-makes-race-debut-scirocco-r-cup/ |title=Volkswagen Motorsport: Pierre Casiraghi makes his race debut in Scirocco R-Cup |publisher=Motoroids |date=2014-04-29 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} == Personal life == [[File:2017-07-08 Wedding Ekaterina Malysheva und Ernst August von Hannover (1340)b.jpg|thumb|left|Pierre Casiraghi with [[Beatrice Borromeo]] (in the foreground right), Ben-Sylvester Strautmann (left) and [[Charlotte Casiraghi]] (in the background with black hat);
in July 2017 in [[Hanover]] at the wedding of Ekaterina Malysheva and [[Prince Ernst August of Hanover (born 1983)|Prince Ernst August of Hanover]]]] It is believed that he uses his economics degree towards learning the business of his father's companies, which are also managed by his uncle Marco.[http://www.hellomagazine.com/royalty/200908251896/pierre-casiraghi/girlfriend/beatrice-monaco/1/ Royal pin-up Pierre Casiraghi goes head over heels for his Italian beauty Beatrice], ''HELLO!'', 25 August 2009. Retrieved 26 April 2012. Casiraghi was linked to a number of young women during his university years in [[Milan]], where he was photographed out and about with fashion models. Casiraghi has been in a relationship with the aristocratic journalist [[Beatrice Borromeo]] since May 2008. They were married in a [[civil ceremony]] on 25 July 2015 in the gardens of the [[Prince's Palace of Monaco]]. The religious ceremony took place on [[Isola Bella (Lago Maggiore)|Isola Bella]] on 1 August 2015.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/brides/2015062225911/pierre-casiraghi-beatrice-borromeo-civil-ceremony-date/ |title=Pierre Casiraghi and Beatrice Borromeo's civil ceremony date confirmed |website=Hellomagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Pierre and Beatrice's first child, Stefano Ercole Carlo, was born on 28 February 2017.{{cite web|url=http://us.hellomagazine.com/royalty/12017022821634/pierre-casiraghi-beatrice-borromeo-royal-baby |title=Pierre Casiraghi and Beatrice Borromeo welcome a baby boy in Monaco |website=Us.hellomagazine.com |date=2017-02-28 |accessdate=2017-03-06}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://us.hola.com/realeza/casa_monaco/2017030291999/nombre-hijo-pierre-casiraghi-beatrice-borromeo-moda/ |title=Exclusiva en HOLA.com: El hijo de Pierre Casiraghi y Beatrice Borromeo se llama Stefano |website=Us.hola.com |date=2017-03-02 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} Their second child, Francesco Carlo Albert was born on 21 May 2018.https://people.com/royals/monaco-pierre-casiraghi-beatrice-borromeo-welcome-son-francesco/ In February 2012, Casiraghi was briefly hospitalized following a physical altercation at a New York nightclub.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/20/prince-monaco-bar-fight-pierre-casiraghi-new-york_n_1289471.html |title=Pierre Casiraghi, Prince of Monaco, Punched In New York Bar Fight |publisher=The Huffington Post |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} According to media reports, Casiraghi approached the table of businessman [[Adam Hock]], models [[Natasha Poly]], [[Anja Rubik]] and [[Valentina Zelyaeva]], whereby words were exchanged and an altercation ensued.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Alison|title=Monaco's Pierre Casiraghi Bloodied in N.Y.C. Bar Brawl|url=http://people.com/crime/pierre-casiraghi-of-monaco-princess-carolines-son-in-nyc-bar-brawl/|publisher=People.com|accessdate=11 November 2017}} Hock was arrested on four counts of assault, and is alleged to have struck Casiraghi as well as three male friends. Hock, who was charged on eight counts of misdemeanor assault,{{cite web|last=Wallace |first=Benjamin |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/scandal/2013/05/model-mogul-nightclub-brawl-double-seven |title=Who Started the Model-Mogul Nightclub Dustup at Meatpacking’s Double Seven? |publisher=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} alleges that Casiraghi was the aggressor and that he assaulted Casiraghi and his companions in self-defence.Mohney, Gillian. [http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2012/02/new-york-nightclub-brawl-sends-monaco-prince-to-the-hospital/ Brawl Sends Monaco Prince to the Hospital], ''ABC News'', 20 February 2012. Retrieved 26 April 2012.Bates, Daniel. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2103755/Monacos-Prince-Pierre-Casiraghi-hospital-nightclub-brawl-Adam-Hock.html Monaco's Prince Pierre Casiraghi left needing hospital treatment after brawl in Manhattan nightclub], ''Daily Mail'', 21 February 2012. Retrieved 26 April 2012. Casiraghi was treated at [[New York Presbyterian Hospital]] for a laceration, bruising, and swelling of his face. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Pierre Casiraghi''' |2= 2. [[Stefano Casiraghi]] |3= 3. [[Caroline, Princess of Hanover|Princess Caroline of Monaco]] |4= 4. Giancarlo Casiraghi |5= 5. Fernanda Biffi |6= 6. [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco]] |7= 7. [[Grace Kelly]] |12= 12. [[Prince Pierre, Duke of Valentinois|Count Pierre of Polignac]] |13= 13. [[Princess Charlotte, Duchess of Valentinois]] |14= 14. [[John B. Kelly Sr.]] |15= 15. [[Margaret Katherine Majer]] |24= 24. Count Maxence of Polignac |25= 25. Susana Mariana de la Torre y Mier |26= 26. [[Louis II, Prince of Monaco]] |27= 27. [[Marie Juliette Louvet]] |28= 28. John Henry Kelly |29= 29. Mary Anne Costello |30= 30. Carl Majer |31= 31. Margaretha Berg }} == External links == {{Commonscat}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-other|line}} {{s-bef|before=[[India Casiraghi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Succession to the Monegasque throne]]|years=7th in line}} {{s-aft|after=[[Stefano Casiraghi (born 2017)|Stefano Casiraghi]]}} {{end}} {{Caroline, Princess of Hanover}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Casiraghi, Pierre}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:House of Grimaldi]] [[Category:Monegasque businesspeople]] [[Category:Grace Kelly]] [[Category:Kelly family]] [[Category:Monegasque people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Monegasque people of American descent]] [[Category:Monegasque Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Monegasque people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Monegasque people of Mexican descent]] [[Category:Monegasque people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Monegasque people of English descent]] [[Category:Monegasque people of German descent]] [[Category:Audi Sport TT Cup drivers]] [[Category:Monegasque sailors (sport)]] [[Category:Monegasque racing drivers]]

Laura Lee
Nancy Ruth (Lee) Todd
(Lee and his wife were also the parents of two stillborn children) | residence = [[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]] | alma_mater = [[The College of William and Mary]] | occupation = [[Planter (American South)|planter]], [[judge]] | profession = | religion = [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopalian]] | signature = Richard Bland Lee Signature.svg | website = | footnotes = | speaker = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = }} '''Richard Bland Lee''' (January 20, 1761 – March 12, 1827) was a planter, jurist, and politician from [[Fairfax County, Virginia]]. He was the son of [[Henry Lee II]] (1730–1787) of "Leesylvania" and Lucy Grymes (1734–1792), as well as a younger brother of both Maj. Gen. [[Henry Lee III|Henry ("Light Horse Harry") Lee]] (1756–1818) and of [[Charles Lee (Attorney General)|Charles Lee]] (1758–1815), [[Attorney General of the United States]] from 1795 to 1801, who served in both the [[George Washington|Washington]] and [[John Adams|Adams]] administrations. ==Early life and education== Richard Bland Lee the third son of [[Henry Lee II]] and Lucy Grymes was born on January 20, 1761 at [[Leesylvania State Park|"Leesylvania"]], the estate built by his father on land overlooking the Potomac River in [[Prince William County, Virginia]]. He was named after two distinguished relatives, his great-grandfather [[Richard Bland (burgess)|Richard Bland]] of "Jordan's Point", and his great-uncle, jurist and statesman [[Richard Bland]], whom Thomas Jefferson called "the wisest man south of the James".Gamble, Robert S. '' Sully: Biography of a House'' (Sully Foundation Ltd: Chantilly, VA, 1973), p. 17 Possibly educated as a youth at "Chantilly", the home of his venerated cousin [[Richard Henry Lee]] in [[Westmoreland County, Virginia]], Richard was enrolled at the [[The College of William & Mary|College of William and Mary]] in 1779. Though not directly involved in the Revolutionary war as his brother [[Henry Lee III]] was, Richard nevertheless took an active interest in the American cause. In June 1779 for example, Richard's uncle [[Richard "Squire" Lee|"Squire" Richard Lee]] of Lee Hall introduced a resolution in the House of Delegates that would authorize the building of a new statehouse. Though only eighteen years of age, Richard Bland Lee, in a letter written later that month, rebuked his famous uncle, characterizing the effort as "abominable...[at a]...time of public danger when our expenses are already unsupportable." On June 17 of the next year Richard was admitted to the [[Phi Beta Kappa Society]], an academic organization through which he was able to refine his speaking skills.Original Records of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, ''William and Mary College Quarterly Magazine'', Richmond, Vol. IV, April 1896 In December of that year, a British invasion fleet transporting newly minted British General [[Benedict Arnold]] and his troops appeared off Jamestown, prepared it seemed, to launch an advance upon Richmond.Randall, Willard Sterne. ''Benedict Arnold: Patriot and Traitor'', (New York, William & Morrow Co., 1990) Phi Beta Kappa undertook to secure its papers against capture, and many of its members joined a hastily formed local militia company to offer at least some resistance to the expected invasion. Richard Bland Lee may have been a part of this militia, or may have earlier returned to "Leesylvania" to "converse with his father about the future." Part of that future had apparently already been decided for him, as his father Henry Lee II had destined a part of his holdings on [[Cub Run]] to Richard, who it appears agreed to act on his father's behalf in managing this property sometime in 1780 or 1781. In 1787, he inherited {{convert|1500|acre|km2}} of this holding from his father, land that would comprise the estate he would later name "[[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]]". ==Public life== ===Virginia House of Delegates=== Richard served as a member of the Virginia House of Delegates from 1784 to 1788, 1796, and again from 1799 to 1806. During his second term in the state legislature he was involved in debates surrounding the ratification of the [[United States Constitution]] which he wholeheartedly supported. Following ratification he opposed efforts by [[Patrick Henry]] and others to call a second constitutional convention to add a bill of rights, believing the new system should be given a chance to operate before wholesale alterations were made. He also believed that the new congress could be trusted to add the necessary amendments. [[Image:Virginia Capitol 1865.jpg|thumb|left|Virginia State Capitol built in 1785, as it appeared in 1865]] It was also during this term that the election of Virginia's first two United States Senators took place. Lee was a strong supporter of [[James Madison]]'s candidacy. Ultimately however, Madison was rejected by the [[Patrick Henry|Henry]] led House of Delegates on the assumption that he would not push for addition of a bill of rights. A contention Lee worked hard to counteract. Following this rejection Lee continued to work on Madison's behalf in his congressional race, proposing publication of letters between Madison and other's ''"...as would counteract the report industriously circulated in the assembly and consequently in the state that you were opposed to every amendment to the new government, and in every mode..."''Richard Bland Lee to James Madison, 17 Nov. 1788(Library of Congress, Richard Bland lee Collection) Unwilling to risk publication of letters critical of others, Madison rejected this idea, but would nevertheless defeat future President [[James Monroe]] in a hard fought contest. In both of these debates Lee recognized the power of Patrick Henry's oratory, lamenting the weakness of opposition to him. In a letter from Lee to Madison he complains:
Our Assembly is weak. Mr. [Patrick] Henry is the only orator we have against us and the friends to the new government being all young and inexperienced, form a feeble bond against him.Richard Bland Lee to James Madison, 29 Oct. 1788 (Library of Congress, Richard Bland lee Collection)
While Henry was ultimately able to get the Virginia legislature to pass the measure urging Congress to call a new constitutional convention, Congress refused to do so, instead passing the first ten amendments to the constitution that make up the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]]. ===US Congress=== [[File:Federal hall02.jpg|thumb|right|''New York City Federal Hall, Seat of Congress.'' 1790 copper engraving by A. Doolittle, depicting Washington's April 30, 1789 inauguration.]] {{quote|I went up to the Election of a Representative to Congress for this district. [V]oted for Richd. Bland Lee Esqr.|'''George Washington'''''The Diaries of George Washington.'' Vol. 5. The Papers of George Washington. Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia, 1979.--February 1789}} In 1788, having served three years in the Virginia House of Delegates, Richard Bland Lee decided to stand for election to the [[1st United States Congress|new federal congress]] established under the recently ratified [[United States Constitution|constitution]]. Though political parties had yet to form, ideological schisms were already developing by time of the first federal election. In general, those who were the strongest supporters of the constitution in the form adopted by the [[Constitutional Convention (United States)|constitutional convention]], including its provision for a strong executive with power tilted toward the federal government were identified as federalists, and those who were less supportive of a strong federal government, and who believed a bill of rights should have been included with the document prior to ratification, anti-federalists. Lee was identified with the former camp. He had strongly supported ratification of the constitution,Bickford, Charlene B. et al. ''The Documentary History of the First Federal Congress, March 4, 1789-March 3, 1791'' (Johns Hopkins University Press) opposed efforts to force a second constitutional convention for the purpose of adding a bill of rights, and was a strong supporter of [[George Washington]]. His district which included his estate Sully, then part of Loudoun County (now Fairfax County), and included [[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax County]], was the home of both Washington as well as future Anti-Federalist leader, [[George Mason]]. Lee eventually became the consensus candidate of the federalists, overcoming competition from like minded men including relative Ludwell Lee, [[William Fitzhugh]], Martin Pickett, as well as two friends - [[Leven Powell]] and [[David Stuart (Virginia)|Dr. David Stuart]]. Opposing him for the anti-federalists was state Senator John Pope. Though there is little primary material describing the tenor of this first election, what does exist hints at a hard fought and sometimes dirty campaign. John Pope was called "contemptible" in a letter from John Murray to [[Horatio Gates]],Letter from John Murray to Horatio Gates, January 9, 1789. ''Horatio Gates Papers'' and William Allason writing to John Woodcock described the contest: ''"I understand one makes very free with the other's Reputation &c by wch. I would not be surprised to hear of their having Exchanged a few dry blows."''Letter from William Allason to John Woodcock. Published in "Important Letters from the Papers of William Allason, Merchant, of Falmouth, VA".,''Richmond College Historical Papers'', II (1917-1918), 174. Lee eventually outpolled Pope, defeating him nearly 4 to 1 in Fairfax County alone, which included the vote of George Washington. On March 3, 1789 Richard Bland Lee began service as the first representative of Northern Virginia in the [[United States House of Representatives]]. He served three terms as a Pro-Administration (federalist) member of congress from 1789 to 1795. He was a party to the [[Compromise of 1790]] by which in exchange for support of southern delegates for federal assumption of state Revolutionary War debt, northern delegates voted to move the Federal City to a location in the south. His participation in this compromise, as well as his adherence to federalist principles proved to be his downfall. He narrowly fended off a challenge from his more famous relative [[Arthur Lee (diplomat)|Arthur Lee]] in 1792, and finally lost his seat to [[Richard Brent (Virginia)|Richard Brent]] in the election of 1794. Following this defeat, Richard was returned to the Virginia House of Delegates in 1795, and again from 1799 to 1806. ====Other government service==== [[Image:US Capitol 1814c.jpg|left|thumb|210px|'''The United States Capitol after the burning of Washington, D.C. in the War of 1812. Watercolor and ink depiction from 1814, restored.''']] Following his removal from "[[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]]" to Washington, DC in 1815, Richard, along with [[John Peter Van Ness]] and [[Tench Ringgold]], was appointed by longtime friend President [[James Madison]] as one of three Commissioners to superintend the reconstruction of the Federal [[Burning of Washington|buildings damaged by British troops]] in the attack on Washington DC on August 24, 1814 during the [[War of 1812]].Allen, William C. '' History of the United States Capitol: A chronicle of design, construction, and politics'' (Government Printing Office: Washington, DC, 2001), p. 101 Following expiration of this commission in 1816 President Madison intended to nominate Lee to the new position of "Commissioner of Public Buildings". However, after learning the Senate would not confirm any of the three members of the previous commission because of their perceived ill treatment of [[Benjamin Henry Latrobe|Benjamin Latrobe]] who had been appointed [[Architect of the Capitol]] in order to aid in its reconstruction, Richard was instead appointed by President Madison as a commissioner to adjudicate claims arising out of the loss or destruction of property during the War of 1812. Lee occupied this position for two contentious years, during which his decisions came in for harsh criticism by Congress. [[John Randolph of Roanoke|John Randolph]] of Virginia accused Lee of "malfeasance," and congress finally appointed a "Committee of Claims" to look into the operation of Lee's office. While Lee himself was exonerated of any corruption, the committee noted that many "claimants had perpetrated an extensive 'system of fraud, forgery, and perhaps perjury." Michele Landis Dauber, The War of 1812, September 11th, and the Politics of Compensation, 53 DePaul L. Rev. 289, 289-90 (2003) With his power severely curtailed, Lee, despondent over his treatment, left his position and for a short time seriously considered moving his family to Kentucky. Realizing his prospects would be limited there, and that his wife opposed the move, he decided to stay in Washington DC. In 1819 he was appointed by President Monroe as a judge of the [[Probate Court#The Orphan's Court|Orphans' Court]] of the District of Columbia, a position he held until his death on March 12, 1827. ===Societies=== During the 1820s, Lee was a member of the prestigious society, [[Columbian Institute for the Promotion of Arts and Sciences]], who counted among their members former presidents [[Andrew Jackson]] and [[John Quincy Adams]] and many prominent men of the day, including well-known representatives of the military, government service, medical and other professions.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MY-5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA118 |title=The Columbian institute for the promotion of arts and sciences: A Washington Society of 1816–1838. |first=Richard |last=Rathbun |accessdate=2010-06-20|work=|publisher=Bulletin of the United States National Museum, October 18, 1917}} ==Planter== [[Image:FallHouse.JPG|right|thumb|210px|'''Sully, Home of Richard Bland Lee''']] Upon his death in 1787, [[Henry Lee II]] bequeathed {{convert|3000|acre|km2}} of his Cub Run estates to be equally divided between his sons Richard Bland and Theodorick. Being the older of the two, Richard was given the more alluvial northern half, on which he already resided, having lived there as manager of the estate since approximately 1781. After his election to Congress, and for most of the next five years, Richard turned day-to-day management of his estate over to his brother Theodorick, who supervised spring planting, fall harvest, collection of rent from tenant farmers, and the construction of the large house Richard had planned for the estate on which construction had begun in 1794. Before he left for Congress in 1789, Richard had chosen a name for his estate, Sully. The exact origin of the name is unknown, though Robert S. Gamble in ''Sully: Biography of a House'' speculates that Sully was named after [[Sully-sur-Loire|"Chateau de Sully"]] in the Valley of Loire in France. According to Gamble, "if he turned to a specific source, it was doubtless the ''Memoires'' of [[Maximilien de Béthune, duc de Sully|Maximilien de Bethune]], Duke of Sully and France's Minister of Finance under Henry IV." This work was well known among wealthy Virginians in the late 18th century. Upon his defeat for reelection to Congress, Richard returned to "[[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]]" and took over primary operation of his estate. Determined to steer clear of the untenable practices characteristic of the tobacco [[monoculture]] which predominated in Virginia, Richard, like [[George Washington]] whom he idolized, applied modern methods of farming designed to diversify production and to halt depletion of the soil. To the end he switched to growing staple crops - wheat, rye, barley, corn and timothy, fruit trees - apple to produce cider, and peach for the making of peach brandy. He planted clover to help replenish the soil and he "tried crop rotation and the application of nutrients, especially crushed limestone, to fields where productivity was decreasing." During this period he either abandoned or severely limited the growing of tobacco at "[[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]]." He planted large vegetable gardens and in 1801 Richard built a dairy house constructed with red [[Seneca Quarry|Seneca stone]]. Construction on the large house was begun in 1794 and completed in 1795. It is a "[[Federal architecture|Federal]]"- or "[[Georgian Architecture|Georgian]]"-style home of two and a half stories. He erected a {{frac|1|1|2}}-story addition in 1799 coincident with the wedding of [[William Lee (diplomat)#Children|Portia Lee]] who, along with her sister [[William Lee (diplomat)#Children|Cornelia Lee]] had come to live with Richard and Elizabeth Lee under their guardianship. Driven into significant debt trying to aid his brothers Maj. Gen. [[Henry Lee III|Henry ("Light Horse Harry") Lee]] and [[Charles Lee (Attorney General)|Charles Lee]] extricate themselves from severe financial difficulties, Richard sold "[[Sully (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Sully]]" in 1811 to a cousin, [[Richard Henry Lee#Francis Lightfoot Lee II|Francis Lightfoot Lee]] (1782–1858). Richard Bland and Elizabeth Lee initially moved to a home in Alexandria, then to a country home called [[Strawberry Vale Manor|Strawberry Vale]] near Scott's Run [http://gfhs.org/oral_hists/rambler_12-31-16.htm] (current site of [[Tysons Corner, Virginia|Tysons Corner]]), and finally to the historic [[Thomas Law House]] at Sixth and N Streets, Southwest in Washington, DC. "Sully" is located at Chantilly, just off U.S. Route 50, on [[State Route 28 (Virginia)|State Route 28]], the southern access road to Dulles International Airport. It is owned and operated as a museum house by the Fairfax County Park Authority. [[Image:Elizabeth (Collins) Lee.JPG|left|thumb|280px|'''Elizabeth (Collins) Lee (c. 1768–1858)''']] ==Marriage== Richard married Elizabeth Collins (c. 1768–1858) in 1794, at her parent's home in Germantown, PA. Elizabeth was the daughter of Philadelphia Quaker merchant Stephen Collins and [[Mary Parrish]], and the sister of [[Zaccheus Collins]], a prominent botanist. Her lifelong friend was [[Dolley Madison|Dolley Payne Todd Madison]]. ==Death== Richard died in [[Washington, D.C.]] and was buried in the [[Congressional Cemetery]] there in 1827. In 1975 he was reinterred at his home, the ''Sully Plantation'' near [[Chantilly, Virginia]]. His home is now open to visitors as a county park. [http://www.fairfaxcounty.gov/parks/sully www.fairfaxcounty.gov/parks/sully] ==Children== # Mary Ann LeeLee Family Bible. Copy of page containing original entries of births and deaths of children of Richard Bland Lee and Elizabeth Collins Lee. Copy in possession of Sully Historic Site, Fairfax County Park Authority born May 11, 1795, died June 21, 1796 of dysentery. Buried at Sully in unmarked grave. # Col. [[Richard Bland Lee II]] born July 20, 1797, died August 2, 1875. Married [[Julia Anna Marion Prosser]] (1806–1882), daughter of [[John Prosser and Mary "Polly" Poole]].Both buried at [http://www.ivyhill.org/ Ivy Hill Cemetery], Alexandria, Va. # [[Ann Matilda Lee]] born July 13, 1799, died December 20, 1880. Married Dr. [[Baily Washington III]] (1787–1854). # [[Mary Collins Lee]] born May 6, 1801, died February 22, 1805. Buried at Sully in unmarked grave. # Laura Lee born May 10, 1803, died in infancy # [[Cornelia Lee]] born March 20, 1804, died December 26, 1876. Married Dr. [[James W. F. Marcrae]]. # Hon. [[Zaccheus Collins Lee]] born December 5, 1805, died November 1859 in Baltimore, MD; Served as [[United States Attorney|U.S. District Attorney]] from 1848 to 1855. Married Martha Jenkins. # Male Infant born April 15, 1807, died April 15, 1807 # Male Infant stillborn June 11, 1809 [[Image:Lee Coat of Arms.JPG|right|thumb|210px|'''Lee Family Coat of Arms''']] ==Ancestry== Richard Bland Lee was the son of [[Henry Lee II]] (1730–1787) of "Leesylvania" and, [[Lucy Grymes]] (1734–1792).Lee, Edmund Jennings MD. ''Lee of Virginia, 1642-1892: Biographical and Genealogical Sketches of the Descendants of Colonel Richard Lee''. *Lucy Grymes Lee was the daughter of Hon. [[Charles Grymes]] (1693–1743) and Frances Jennings. Henry Lee, II, was the third son of Capt. [[Henry Lee I]] (1691–1747) of "Lee Hall", Westmoreland County, and his wife, [[Mary Bland]] (1704–1764). *Mary Bland Lee was the daughter of Hon. [[Richard Bland (burgess)|Richard Bland I]] (1665–1720) and his second wife, [[Elizabeth Randolph]] (1685–1719). Henry Lee, I, was the son of Col. [[Richard Lee II]], Esq., "the scholar" (1647–1715) and [[Laetitia Corbin]] (c. 1657–1706). *Laetitia Corbin Lee was the daughter of Richard's neighbor and, Councillor, Hon. [[Henry Corbin, Sr.]] (1629–1676) and [[Alice (Eltonhead) Burnham]] (c. 1627–1684). Richard Lee, II, was the son of Col. [[Richard Lee I]], Esq., "the immigrant" (1618–1664) and [[Anne Constable]] (c. 1621–1666). *Anne Constable Lee was the daughter of [[Thomas Constable]] and a ward of [[Sir John Thoroughgood]]. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=L000200 Biographic sketch at U.S. Congress website] *[http://www.co.fairfax.va.us/parks/sully/ Sully Historic Site in Fairfax County, Virginia] *[http://centreville.patch.com/blog_posts/what-is-this-sully-i-see-everywhere What is this Sully I see Everywhere] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Virginia | district=4 | before=''District established'' | after=[[Francis Preston]] | years=1789–1793}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Virginia | district=17 | before=''District established'' | after=[[Richard Brent (Virginia)|Richard Brent]] | years=1793–1795}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Richard Bland}} [[Category:1761 births]] [[Category:1827 deaths]] [[Category:Lee family of Virginia]] [[Category:College of William & Mary alumni]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Virginia]] [[Category:Members of the Virginia House of Delegates]] [[Category:Burials at the Congressional Cemetery]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:American slave owners]] [[Category:People from Prince William County, Virginia]] [[Category:18th-century American politicians]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:19th-century American judges]] [[Category:People from Chantilly, Virginia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Rod Drury<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = Rod Drury, NZ Open Source Awards, 2007.jpg | caption = Drury in 2007 at the New Zealand Open Source Awards | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1966}} | birth_place = Wellington, New Zealand | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | = | nationality = New Zealander | net worth = $600 million (2017) | occupation = technology entrepreneur | known_for = founding [[Xero (software)|Xero]] }} '''Rodney Kenneth Drury''' (born 1966) is a New Zealand technology entrepreneur. He is the founder and former CEO of the online accounting software company [[Xero (software)|Xero]]. He also is a former director of [[Trade Me]],<ref>{{Cite news|title = No guts, no glory for Xero boss|url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/10519659/No-guts-no-glory-for-Xero-boss|newspaper = Stuff.co.nz|date = 2014-09-21|access-date = 2016-01-04|language = English|first = Sally|last = Rose}}</ref> and was a key player in the now-defunct [[Pacific Fibre]] project.
== Early life == Drury is the son of a tradesman and an executive assistant.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10775278|title=Leading questions: Rod Drury|date=2011-12-25|work=NZ Herald|access-date=2018-07-25|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}}</ref> He grew up in [[Hawke's Bay]], where his father traced a lineage to [[Ngāi Tahu]].<ref name="november2017">[https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/98987177/rod-drury-from-surf-and-software-to-shares-and-social-endeavours Rod Drury: from surf and software to shares and social endeavours]</ref> He was raised in a middle-class family and had only a vague idea of his [[Māori people|Māori]] ancestry.<ref>[http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/comment/columnists/9595156/Market-whizz-kid-enjoys-Kiwi-lifestyle Market whizz-kid enjoys Kiwi lifestyle]</ref>
Drury attended [[Napier Boys' High School]], where he developed an interest in computer programming.<ref name="november2017" /> He went on to study commerce and administration at [[Victoria University of Wellington]]. After university, he worked at the accounting firm Arthur Young, which became [[Ernst & Young]] in 1989.<ref name=":0" />
== Career == In 1995, Drury established [[Glazier Systems]], a New Zealand software development and consulting company. Glazier Systems was acquired by Advantage Group<ref name="Idealog profile">{{cite web | url=http://www.idealog.co.nz/magazine/7/repeat-offender/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207094619/http://www.idealog.co.nz/magazine/7/repeat-offender/ | archivedate=7 February 2013| title=Rod Drury: Repeat offender | work=idealog | date=13 December 2006 | accessdate=4 May 2015 | author=Cooney, Matt}}</ref> in 1999 for approximately $7.5 million.<ref name="Dom Post profile"/> Drury subsequently founded and served as CEO of AfterMail which was acquired by [[Quest Software]] (subsequently acquired by [[Francisco Partners]] and [[Elliott Management Corporation]]).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/06/20/confirmed-dell-sells-software-division-to-francisco-partners-and-elliott-management/|title=Confirmed: Dell sells software division to Francisco Partners and Elliott Management|last=Miller|first=Ron|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en}}</ref>
In July 2006 Drury founded [[Xero (software)|Xero]], a publicly listed [[software as a service]] accounting-software company, and served as its CEO.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/better-business/9295899/Xero-founder-Rod-Drury-takes-entrepreneur-prize | title=Xero founder Rod Drury takes entrepreneur prize | publisher=Fairfax | work=Stuff.co.nz | date=17 October 2013 | accessdate=4 May 2015 | author=Moore, Martin}}</ref>
In October 2007, Drury was a judge for the [[New Zealand Open Source Awards]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nzosa.org.nz/judges | title=New Zealand Open Source Awards |date=2007-10-17| accessdate=2008-05-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080509130322/http://www.nzosa.org.nz/judges |archivedate = 2008-05-09}}</ref>
Drury co-founded Pacific Fibre, a company which attempted to build an internet cable between Australia, New Zealand, and the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/4521214/Pacific-Fibre-adds-Facebook-and-Paypal | title=Pacific Fibre adds Facebook and Paypal | work=Stuff.co.nz | date=8 January 2011 | accessdate=4 May 2015 | author=McBeth, Paul}}</ref> The cable would have cost around $400 million but the venture was ultimately unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10824153 | title=Politics helped kill cable | publisher=NZME | work=The New Zealand Herald | date=3 August 2012 | accessdate=4 May 2015 | author=Fletcher, Hamish}}</ref>
In November 2017, he sold $95 million worth of shares in Xero, leaving him with a 13 per cent holding in the company. He stated the sale would support his "future plans to pursue a range of philanthropic and social endeavours." He stepped down as CEO of Xero in March 2018, continuing on with the company as a non-executive director.<ref>[https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/101976251/rod-drury-stands-down-as-ceo-of-xero Rod Drury stands down as CEO of Xero, replaced by Aussie]</ref>
===Awards=== Drury was awarded the Hi-Tech New Zealand "Entrepreneur of the Year" award in 2006 and 2007.<ref name="Idealog profile" /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hitech.org.nz/ | title=Hi-Tech Awards site |date=2007-11-03| accessdate=2008-05-11}}</ref>
In August 2008 Drury was conferred the title of ''Honorary Fellow of the [[New Zealand Computer Society]]'' (HFNZCS) during the 2008 NZ Computerworld Excellence Awards. He is only the 21st person to be awarded the title in the Society's 48-year history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iitp.org.nz/about/honfellows |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710045646/http://www.iitp.org.nz/about/honfellows |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 July 2012 |title=Honorary Fellows of the IITP (HFIITP) |work=About the IITP |publisher=Institute of IT Professionals of New Zealand |accessdate=25 April 2013 }}</ref>
In 2012, Drury was awarded NZ Herald Business Leader of the Year.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Business leader of the year: Rod Drury|url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10854152|newspaper = New Zealand Herald|date = 2012-12-15|access-date = 2016-01-04|issn = 1170-0777|language = en-NZ}}</ref>
In 2013, Drury was named Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the year.<ref name="Dom Post profile">{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/comment/columnists/9595156/Market-whizz-kid-enjoys-Kiwi-lifestyle|title=Market whizz-kid enjoys Kiwi lifestyle|author=Anthony Hubbard|date=2014-01-10|publisher=The Dominion Post}}</ref>
In 2014, Drury was honoured with an award for the Outstanding Contribution to Technology in NZ at the CIO Awards 2014.
==Personal life== {{As of|2016}}, he lives in a "high-tech townhouse" in Havelock North, Hawke's Bay region with his family.<ref name="Dom Post profile" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Local lifestyle, global dominion for Bay’s hi-tech ambassador|url = http://www.baybuzz.co.nz/archives/6386/|website = www.baybuzz.co.nz|access-date = 2016-01-04}}</ref> He also enjoys surfing and skateboarding in his free time.<ref name=":0" />
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{commons category|Rod Drury}} *{{Twitter}} *[http://socialmedianz.com/smnz-tv/2011/03/02/social-media-nz-interview-2-talking-xero-and-social-media-with-rod-drury/ Interview with Drury], Social Media NZ
{{DEFAULTSORT:Drury, Rod}} [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Ngāi Tahu]] [[Category:People educated at Napier Boys' High School]]
